star_trek_picard.review:
The first season was passable, if flawed. This second season, however, is absolute gorn-spew. Almost the entire season takes place on contemporary earth. The costumes look cheap and the dialogue is flat. They gave Picard some kind of sad childhood backstory that we've never heard of and it felt forced.

The worst thing, though, is the laziness of the writing:
[Begin Spoilers] They massively retcon one of the most consistent details in Star Trek (how Borg assimilation works) just so characters could steal information from the Borg queen, then later in the season it's revealed off-handedly that the ship they've been on (with the Borg queen) can just replicate anyone who has ever been aboard as a hologram with all of that person's skills, personality and knowledge. They could have just gotten the info from the ship's reconstruction of the Borg queen without the nonsense retcon! Nevermind how overpowered a ship with that capability would be going forward.
[End Spoilers]

I'd say take a pass on this season. If you're a Trekkie, it'll just make you mad.

Can I give this negative stars? The only resdeeming quality of Picard Seasons 1 and 2 is that they are retconned into a fever dream by season 3. Thank you for season 3. But seasons 1 and 2 should have every copy burned to ash.

This season has some writing problems. And probably it was hard to write and film, with all the show-runner changes in the background and dealing with COVID imposed restriction. Like the end cut come to late or to early, depending on how you look at it. Still, it is enjoyable as a Star trek fan as it has a lot of connections to pas series especially TOS and TNG. And it leaves a lot of questions to answer in the future of Star Trek, like what is that transwarp hub opening, what will happen with the Jurati-collective,I want to know more about the Travelers and the Supervisors ... And with all the frustrations of the season there are 4 really amazing episodes, and the hug between JL and Q at the end is precious. So yeah, watch it, and even binge-watch it if you can because it is better that way.

"Star Trek: Picard" - Season Two Review

Season Two endeavors to address some of Season One's shortcomings by delving into the world of nostalgia. As we see familiar faces, it's a bittersweet reminder of what the series could've been from the outset, considering its titular character. Though the use of legacy characters brings a certain warmth, it still feels like a delayed satisfaction, a reaction rather than a planned narrative choice. The core issue remains: the essence of Star Trek's character-driven storytelling feels conspicuously absent. The looming shadow of Alex Kurtzman's influence continues to be felt, much to the chagrin of longtime Trek fans.

While some writing decisions left me wondering what the showrunners were thinking (Too many unnecessary mini plots), overall this is a good series, and it's very underrated by some fans. For those feeling that it's not classic Trek, you're right, it isn't. Every era of Star Trek has felt different as they reflect the times they're made in. Compare the latter episodes of The Next Generation era with the original Kirk movies and they feel totally different in character and atmosphere. And those movies feel totally different to the original episodes of Star Trek, such as The Cage. On top of that, every series of Star Trek after the original (including TNG) has met with fans dumping on them and saying they don't feel like Star Trek. Fans said TNG wasn't Trek because it was a different crew. DS9 wasn't Trek because it was on a station instead of a ship. And I remember fans who couldn't stand Janeway at first. And don't get me started on how underappreciative fans were of Enterprise. But if you can accept that a new series of Star Trek will have a unique feel, and try new things, especially seeing as Picard is set in a new era, over 20 years after the events of Nemesis, you might hopefully appreciate what this show does right. It's very faithful to the lore of it's universe and covers a lot of ground in showing how the politics of the various galactic factions have evolved or changed, for better or worse. Most importantly, Picard is still Picard, an altruistic but stubborn diplomat who maintains optimism and ethics in the face of more cynical forces.

For those of you who want your Star Trek without space, Starfleet, the Federation or in the future; and desperatey want your Star Trek on Earth, in the now times, in the United States (because Federation now means Earth and Earth now means USA), can never get enough of beating the dead horse of the convoluted Soong family tree where every Soong from every generation looks like a Data clone, and loves internal flashbacks set in an Earth-bound historical dreamscape--will LOVE this season. These people have no clue what good scifi is. They have removed it of its science, its speculative and educational aspects and the endless wonder and fear of outer space. Instead they have turned Star Trek into just another mediocre action series. And this is coming from someone whose favourite Trek caharcter of all time is PICARD!

Picard Season 2 is a fantastic continuation of the Star Trek franchise and a worthy successor to the critically acclaimed first season. The show continues to impress with its gripping storyline, excellent character development, and stunning visual effects.
One of the standout elements of this season is its storytelling. The writers have done an excellent job balancing the action-packed scenes with emotional moments that tug at the heartstrings. The plot contains surprises and twists, keeping the audience engaged and invested in the characters' journeys.
Patrick Stewart once again delivers an outstanding performance as Jean-Luc Picard, portraying the character with the same depth and nuance that fans have come to expect. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with each member adding to the show's overall quality.
The show's visual effects remain top-notch, immersing the audience in a futuristic world filled with advanced technology and breathtaking scenery. The production design is exceptional, with meticulous attention to detail that brings each scene to life.
Another significant highlight of this season is the exploration of complex themes, including identity, legacy, and the consequences of our actions. The show tackles these issues with sensitivity and intelligence, offering thought-provoking insights that will leave audiences reflecting long after the credits have rolled.

I think that Season 2 is a VAST improvement over Season 1, which I had to slog through. I wasn't looking forward to watching Picard at all, & the first episode I thought, oh no, they're having Patrick Stewart, at 82 years old, be the greatest, most vicious killer of all in a revised timeline? No no no, this doesn't work! They've totally jumped the shark!!

But, then things started to happen. The gang got back together. The story took off & Stewart didn't have to be the evil monster, (although he did do a decent job of being aggressive & loud once or twice). The story evolved, went different ways, then came back together. More characters were added, friends from the past, but not gratuitously, rather the storyline was enhanced by their presence.  We were thrilled to see them, & they fit in the story.

Each cast member has their strengths and they're put to use beautifully in both scripting & acting. The overall plot is brilliant, the plot & pace is perfect & it makes you want to watch every second of these 10 shows, even watch them again. It ramped up the tension & excitement in every episode right to the end. We wanted to binge watch it in one night! But, we had to you know, sleep & work. 

I highly recommend this Season of Picard, & can't wait for Season 3!

Woof.  Despite a few issues, I kinda liked Season 1.  But this... just made little sense. The way-too-drawn-out trek thru Picard's past trauma was rough, but i guess when you make it the point of the series you have to deal.  But in their alternate timline, they all happen to be even more important than in their standard?  Like Seven happens to be president?  Picard greatest war hero ever? Really?  Pretty convenient and far-fetched. More of the same for other characters.  Ok, moving on... Raffi is such an off-putting character; always irrational, complaining, and addict, basically a mess.. yet somehow just really competent Starfleet material brilliant when randomly needs to be.  Just an unbelievable character that is too many things at once, that don't work together. And both she (formerly married to male and has kid) and Seven of Nine are both suddenly gay, romantically attracted to each other?  Ugh... just makes no sense.  No chemistry, and seemingly no reason Seven should be interested in that intolerable character.  There's more, but why bother with nit picking, there's plenty of major issues as is.
It's not the best acted show on Earth, but this is the mature science fiction Star Trek fans should enjoy. Make it so!

Worse than Season 1 in terms of the story, that is heavily derivative --e.g., time-travel to 2024 Earth, Q messing with JL --, messes with elements of STNG, and is not cohesive.

Season 2 shares with Season 1 clunky story-telling and directing, and spotty acting, that actually worsens in Season 2 -- e.g., JLP appears to be mainly "mailing in" his performance, Dr. Agnes repeats the same "mad/troubled genius/scientist" routine (it was interesting the first time), Raffi continues overacting, and Seven's talents are wasted (and she appears embarrassed by her dialogue).  By episode 5, you will have ceased to care about the story or characters;  only hearty devotion to STNG or mild curiosity (including how poor this season can get) will keep you watching until the end. 

For Star Trek NG devotees only -- and even many of them will get frustrated and angry at the wasted opportunities to make an interesting and meaningful TV series.

Thank you!! As a long time Star Trek fan growing up watching and loving these characters, it's wonderful to have such closure. It's freaking beautiful. I bawled like a baby. Much love to you all and your families! 🙏💞🤗

i liked this a whole lot better than discovery train wreck, this one i actually wound up binge watching, while with discovery i had to force myself to watch a couple episodes(couldnt make it through a whole episode in one sitting by no means) before deciding it wasnt for me. Discovery makes rise of skywalker look like the phantom menace by comparison.

Season 2 of Picard relies heavily on all the classic and overused idea of going back in time to save the future. Sure it's nice to see Q & Picard reunited and Q messing with Picard's mind, but sadly the writers of this series have turned Star Trek into a sad parody of itself. Sure it's clever to tap into all the nostalgia and pick off the popular bad guys as a core to the story but I'm pretty sure all this has been seen before on Star Trek Next Generation. Smash together STTNG First Contact with STTHG Best Of Both Worlds, add a lost memory that gets way too much airtime and reflections and you have Picard S2. Back in the 90's this story could have been a tightly told ‘classic' double episode of STTHG, but all we seem to get now is shows produced to milk out watch times on streaming platforms. If this show was serious and understood the fear factor of Q they would have had John De Lancie seen always as the un aged Q and that would have really added a visual shock to the story. Considering the powers of the Q in the story folk lore it just feels like the writers & producers don't understand what's important to focus on and what's important to drop. What was really obvious was how so much of this season is milked with slow & repeated storytelling yet the final episode is like a sprint to the finish line. And once you get to the end you wished you had never started the race. The ending was weak, pointless and lacked anything to say it was an important story to tell.
Yeah this could've been so much better. Not a fan of the time travel angle or Q. 10 episodes to convince Picard it's ok to love?
Picard once refused to accept murder as an option. Now he has two cold blooded killers hanging out with him. The future used to be bright and thats what i liked

There is no bottom one can't reach without writing talent and with big pockets. The viewer is taken by the storm of "wtf is happening" action and flushed down the toilet together with the plot. By the end of season, I was left with feeling that I just got ripped off - nothing happened, everything is useless; the big mistery promised in the beginning turned out to be only some cheap pompous fart.
Absolutely adore this show. I'm a huge fan of Next Generation and this show scratches all those same itches. Phenomenal writing, cast, special effects, and an endearing story.

If Patrick Stewart wasn't involved with this, it would be just another forgettable gritty modern sci-fi show. As a fan of classic 90s Star Trek, this took everything I loved from that and threw it in the trash. I liked Star Trek because it was uplifting and hopeful for the future. This (and Discovery) got rid of all the cheesy feel-good parts of Star Trek and replaced it with boring gritty generic garbage. Season 2 is even worse than Season 1. It was so bad I couldn't even finish it. Which is absurd considering I love Star Trek so much I even have a Star Trek tattoo. But this show and Discovery are not for classic fans. These shows are entirely made to get new fans rather than to appeal to older fans.

The main plot of the season was a nice idea but the means of getting through it was a mess. Unnecessary and repetitive  flash backs to Picard's past . Simplification of intercharacter relations ... It is as really a mess after the first 2-3 episodes ... Sad
Thought season 2 was awful.

Horrible!  Apparently the writers either know nothing or have ignored the years of Star Trek seasons that the characters are based on.  By definition, Star Trek is science fiction.  Story lines should intertwine and be consistent through series, but not in Picard.  e.g. Picard and Guinan have meet several times in the past, but in this series no one remembers that.  Seven has the most experience in Time Travel, she has done it so often she was warned not to travel any more, but no mention of that either...as well as 1000 other plot holes.  Had to stop watching before my brain exploded.  If you are fan of Star Trek, beam away fast.

Not really any better than season 1.  Still plagued with terrible writing, terrible dialogue, lack of respect for canon, and terrible overall production.  They chose the wrong writers for new Star Trek.  It's awful.

Season 1 was bearable, but Seasons 2 is so poorly executed. Confusing scene changes, spontaneous plot developments, convoluted dialogue — I'm watching this only out of a sense of loyalty to the franchise.

I've always preferred Star Trek over Star Wars — ah yes, the good old debate — but I find the new SW series so entertaining and compelling; they are a model of how clear and straight forward storytelling can and should be. And the set design, the costumes and makeup, everything is spot on. What a stark contrast to Picard. Patrick Stewart deserves better than this.
As a Next Generation fan I'm sorry that you cannot rate something as a 0 in this site. This is not the borg, this is not picard, this is not star trek
Edge of my seat, watching the quest follow thru, I wish there could be another season. Picard is of the best Captains in the franchise's history.

Confusing story, unnecessary scenes, wasted time to tell something simple. Relationship between two characters in the last episode totally unnecessary, meaningless and that adds nothing to the series. A shame. Patrick Stewart is the only reason to watch it.

There are doubts from the start, with the writers relying on the same old antagonists, and the same old time travel routine, but they flip the script in a very unexpected way so that the antagonists become protectors. I think that was much better than expected.

That said, why did they reuse so many of the same actors--was it a COVID issue? It's also hard to reconcile Q's plan to stop Renee with his ultimate goal to help Picard.  They perhaps could have explained that more.  How is Dr. Soong able to create Data, or Lore, 400 years later?  Why does Data eventually build twin robots who look just like the girl created by Dr. Soong?  Was Will Wheaton's appearance at all necessary or even interesting?  Are they going to revisit Kahn?  It is extraordinarily convenient that Dr. Soong apparently creates Kahn, who would be Data's other brother?

Why does Jerati as the Borg Queen tell Picard to look up in Ep 1?  

The entire season, in a nutshell, is Q helping Picard deal with the trauma of his mother's suicide.  That's a hard one.  I dont know if it lifts the season or drags it down. The scenes with his mother certainly are a drag and you know almost from the onset, when they introduce her, where it's heading.  It's still very disturbing to see and I'd rather them have not shown us her final act.  It's not really why people turn to Star Trek.  However, due to the decades associated with the character, it is arguably acceptable.  S3 is coming, I hope it's a good send off for the SNG crew.

Not Star Trek. Politically relevant to 2021?? The entire draw of the show is a utopian future where we are taught how much better things could be. In trying to be 'relatable' Picard has failed to be the role model that stands above the rest.
I got through 2 episodes of season 2 and gave up. That series is nothing but a vehicle for all the TNG actors to goof around with each other in the Star Trek world and get paid.

Season 2 was significantly better than the first season. But when you started off so low, it shouldn't have been hard to do.  The wokeism has been dialled down but it's still there. But at least they paid more attention to story & characterization drawn from TNG roots. I also enjoyed the Star Trek IV: Voyage home vibes. 
This season had a more of the real Picard. The exploration of his background was a great idea. I liked that they brought back things that made ST:TNG great, the Borg queen, Seven, Guinan but most especially John de Lancie's Q. Q was the best part of season 2. Overall, pretty entertaining for this classic Star Trek fan.

I have been watching Star Trek for YEARS.  Over and over again.  The soul of Star Trek was lost in Picard.  It's just names and faces we know, with no soul to be found.  Picard is a weakened frightened old man just swept up in the circumstances around him.  Where before, he was a leader that helped those after him to understand what they were looking at and to not be swept up in the moment, but to look at it objectively with all things considered.  This show is a tragedy.  Clearly the writers have no idea what Star Trek TNG was all about.
Bad acting, bad makeup, special effects weren't bad, but the story was so poorly put together and so contrived it made me cringe.
This was so ridiculously bad it was unbelievable
This season could have been one episode. There's nothing else to say other than what everyone else has said. This show is horrific someone call Seth McFarlen and give him control.
so bad so bad so bad

As a Trek fan it was terrible.  It pretty much ignores, contradicts, and flies in the face of what's been established in Star Trek (Spoilers: humanity is just as rotten as it is today without explanation, money is again a thing without explanation, addiction is a thing again without explanation).  Fans will care cause they're curious to see what happened to their favorite characters, but will only be disappointed.  This show has a habit of grabbing the most fan-favorite characters and tropes, and then ruining them.  These things should've only been revisited if done right.  Looking at it as a non-fan perspective, it's just flat bad story, and I don't know why a non-fan would even care.   The only great things about the show such as the special effects, costumes, art-direction can't save an extremely poor story.
I couldn't finish the season and I am a huge Star Trek fan.  I made it to like episode three I think I was done

After binge-watching the season, it dawned on me that if this were a movie and an editor had removed all the extraneous scenes and whittled it down to 2 hours, it would be a decent Star Trek flick.  The basic premise is excellent with a moving conclusion.  Unfortunately it's 300 minutes too long with extraneous scenes, dialog, sophomoric soapboxing, and illogical plot lines.

You can't tack this kind of thing on such an established character. And the borg queen is just being.....yawn....what were we talking about?

Who let B.O. back in the writing room cuz def felt someone was doing many cocaines! 
Oof. Oof. Oof. I give this season 4 oofs!

Season 2 was working itself up to a good ending.  Maybe a 3 or 4.  Then, they blew it 20 min. before the end.  Raffi went completely out of character and had multiple emotional break downs in back to back scenes.  Something tells me there were suppose to be other scenes in there to spread that out.  Then Seven of Nine is suddenly in Star Fleet and a Captain or something when they said they "tried" to get her in before.  Then there's this whole politically correct stuff.  It's going to be tough trying to watch Season 3 if they don't change things.  Maybe I'll wait until it's all over.  It's destroying my faith in Star Trek.

While I disagreed with some of their creative decisions in episodes 3-6. I thought it started out and ended strong. There should have been more explanation for what was going on with Yvette, Q's plan and a tighter pull on loose ends. I was picking up what they were putting down, but it seems much of the audience didn't. Suggested viewing of TNG episodes Tapestry and All Good Things.

The fact that I binge watched it in two nights probably tells you all you need to know - I really enjoyed it and was hooked to see what would happen from episode to episode. I grew up watching Trek on BBC 2 in the early 90s while eating dinner, so I'm always going to be somewhat nostalgic when it comes to anything TNG related, and while the show format is very different, there's a lot to like. 

Yes, I'd maybe want a few more shots of various Federation ships in space and more time spent in the far future (I'm pretty sure they left plenty of ‘butterflies' in 2024!). But I'm impressed they were able to build out some decent backstory and depth for a character we already thought we knew so well, without retconning anything.

That said, a few less flashbacks would have been appreciated, they got a bit monotonous and slowed the pace down.

One of the greatest fictional leaders in modern sci-fi is sadly used reduced to nothing, Picard has lost his intelligence, compassion and charisma. Sadly this is so far from TNG it feels embarrassing to refer to it as trek. But got to squeeze those pennies from an expensive IP.

Season 1 was a great emotional roller-coaster ride of nostalgia and wonder, but that roller-coaster ran off the rails in Season 2.  It became a bad acid trip that just kept getting worse.  So far fetched it became painful to watch.  What a waste of such great talents.
As a massive lifelong ST fan, this didnt engage (pardon the pun) me.  Weak screenplay and Patrick Stewart now really too old to make it buzz.  Please dont drag this out any  longer.

This is essentially a reworked, stretched-out version of First Contact. The premise, and first episode, is strong. Like a lot of peak TV era shows, there's simply too much content here and not enough substance to justify the length. Could have been a great 2-hour movie; at 10 episodes long, at least 3-4 episodes feel entirely unnecessary. Picard, as a character, is still completely compelling and ripe for story possibilities. Fingers crossed they can find a way to make everything feel more substantial and cohesive for a third season.

So disappointed as a lifelong Star Trek fan.  They focused on "woke" storylines instead of delivering on the science fiction that has made the Star Trek universe so compelling for so many years - don't bother with this one.

Spoiler alert: the Borg queen was just lonely and  all they had to do to defeat her was to convince her only to assimilate for good. Also Wesley Crusher is now some kind of time traveling fabric of time watcher person.

This character could have faded with a wonderful legacy. But screw that I guess.  It meanders from one melodramatic monologue to the next.
This show is terrible.
This was extremely painful to watch. I wanted to like it, but the story does not make any logical sense and so poorly written. Did the writers collectively suffer a stroke before writing the plot?

As a ST:TNG fan I wanted to like Picard. 

Sadly it's a convoluted mess written by woke Hollywood hacks who clearly don't understand the appeal of Roddenberry-era Star Trek. 

Nonsensical plot lines. Established foes (the Borg for example) become shallow, silly caricatures. Far too much of Picard "haunted by his past" or delivering "inspirational and heartwarming speeches," rather than solving problems in clever and authoritative TNG style. No, what we have here is just lazy by-the-numbers storywriting. 

Self-indulgent leftwing political talking points delivered in patronising, non-artistic style. 

Every TNG reference and character feels derivative and misplaced. Every new character seems a misfit in the Star Trek canon. Contrived and dull (Elnor). Completely Un-Starfleet-worthy (Rios, Raffie). Unfunny comic relief (Jurati). Laris is a little more interesting and likeable, but what is an Irish Romulan doing as Picard's house maid? It makes no sense at all. 

I'm torn. Plod on to see the cast reunion in series three? Or leave my last memories of the crew of the Enterprise 1701D intact and untainted?
Soo boring, the first season was just meh... but this one has been really difficult to watch till the end. I love quite everyting about Star Trek but i'm not gonna watch the next season.
Painful to watch. No sustenance. No vision. No Art. Joyless.

Picard season 2
Season 2 begins without calling for season one. Did we forget that, or do the new owners just have something more to their liking? The series starts in France, where Picard is breeding wines like an idiot, exposing the vine bottles to the sun. When the script is written by uneducated people, that's what you get... Afterward, we see him as a young boy with a Basque beret. To complete the caricature, he lacks a baguette under his arm. The French don't wear Basque berets since the 30s, but the stupid scriptwriters had to find pictures on the internet to see what a Frenchman looks like. It's slow, it doesn't move at a sci-fi pace. We left the series in the hands of a failed artist who thinks he's doing melodrama? Twenty minutes have passed since the beginning. And to say what: NOTHING. Nothing but nonsensical chatter that ends with a parody of a speech at the Academy...
Episode 2 has more movement and seems to go somewhere to understand that Q, with an incomprehensible speech, enters the scene to give a lesson to Picard! Why him? We don't know because Q's speech is gibberish...
Episode 3 is even more confusing. The bad writers seem to discover the upcoming scenes on the fly. Even Picard and 7-of-9 don't know where they are any more. Classic conflict situations with the team doubting while Picard seems defeated and accepting a fate in the hands of the Borg Queen. They are led by the Queen to 2024. Why? You don't want to ask those kinds of questions, apparently. The writers are improvising with patches from other Star Trek series. One wonders if the script is written by AI putting together cuts from old episodes?
Before, this kind of story was done for one episode, while here the background is diluted over several episodes. It's boring and sometimes caricatural. When the goal is only commercial, Gene Roddenberry must be turning in his grave. The son does not make the weight. The nature sometimes rests...
Star Trek has a history of using Star Trek for political purposes, preaching and playing along with The View & MSNBC talking points. So disappointed that you keep doing this and make it so obvious.

If I have to see a young Jean-Luc running through the dungeons of Chateau Picard chasing his mother, I will barf. Too many flashbacks, too much obsession with JL's childhood memories and fears, and too little real Trek (and I'm not a 'trekkie'). The worst thing: totally dismantling TNG's greatest contributions to ST: Q and the Borg. But little JL constantly (with his mommy issues) crying out in (poor) French "Maman! Maman!) Yuck. It doesn't square with TNG or other Treks, and was boring and repetitive in spots. Sappy ending. Don't look forward to the final, 5th, season.

Picard is a well-made TV show. It has phenomenal acting, special effects, 
beauty, dialogue, directing, set-design etc. It's just not Star Trek. The show is 
so fixated on giving characters a happy send off that it will literally
spend all its episodes building a bridge to that end and it does so 
by using every brick of nostalgia it can find. Hell, even Wesley Crusher
shows up for this one.This is not the final frontier. This is the backyard.
And the problems don't stop there. Fans get a folksy Picard, a band
of bland unlikable characters and terrible Star Trek lore (the federation managed
to defeat the Borg?). Apparently the writers also thought the fans would love
to see loads of scenes about a boy looking for his mother in a chateau. Overall,
Picard just feels uninteresting and overly sentimental while the action just seems to be filler until the next character can pontificate about life, loss, love and the universe.

I am a big TNG fan. This show was not made for me. It seems to have a disrespect for the established events and characters of the franchises. It suffers from the same affection that modern TV/movies have. The creators plan the story around scenes they want to shoot, regardless of how disjointed it makes the story.
I wanted to give season two a chance to see if it could course correct after season one, but instead it doubled down.

Season 1 of Picard was OK and had some very good moments, enough to have me looking forward to season 2. Wow, was I wrong. Season 2 was nothing but dysfunctional political rhetoric. A chaotic story jumping around without direction most of the time. I wish I had not wasted my time watching it.

Watching this felt like a chore I was forced to do out of politeness towards the actors. Badly written, badly acted, pointless plots and I have zero empathy for the characters. Season 1 was ok, but Season 2 is just bad tv.

Hollywood somehow thinks we care about the inner life of every major character--we don't. This whole season is about redeeming the inner life of Picard, a character that needs no redemption. Just because most artists are in therapy doesn't mean we want to watch a season's worth of episodes that add up to a deep therapy session in a Star Trek season. Ugh.
I finally watched the whole season.   Its sooooooo bad.  I found myself bored as can be, and every plot is guessable.  the acting is trash.  its just bad

Wow, did not think a second season could be worse, but this one was. UGH!

A devastatingly soul-crushing needless failure.

Picard, from season one to its season two ending, shows itself to be (a) one part what happens when a company hires sub-par talent to create a show, then refuses to fire these people when their failure to live up to, let alone evolve past, its roots sinks into the foul and tepid rotten swamp water of its own inevitable despair and (b) one part forcing a vapid and selfish project onto an audience in such a poor disjointed manner to where only sub-par and vapid people could ever find joy or meaning in it.

     Unearned emotional development and divergent pandering of feeling takes away from whatever impact the failed scenes of wonder and connection could have achieved in the hands of those who could have created something meaningful. After the ends credits rolled, I'd have settled for adequacy as much as one lost in the desert would settle for finding a bottle of water with the cap off.

     It's a shameful insult to acting, producing, writing, thinking, business, and creativity. It's a cruelly ignorant display of mediocrity foisted upon us by three generations of protected yet talentless film-makers who, after two years of flailing first drafts put to screen, instead of the recycle bin, were still unable tell us a good story.

     The only take away one gains from watching Picard is that those involved would make a better and more meaningful impact on the world if they were being dropped into the Black Sea as mine clearers rather than be allowed to ever be involved in any aspect of story-telling ever again.

     It's dolorously and childishly wretched to the point it actually ruins the memory of prior accomplishments of talented people who aren't involved and sullied the good name of those who were dragged back in.

Just binged watched Star Trek: Picard. Wow. It so reminded me of the bad holodeck episodes that spanned a couple of episodes where the cast are trapped in another reality and must unify to get out. The problem was that after seven or eight episodes, I came to realize that we were trapped in that holodeck as well.

I don't know who constructed this story, but they really need to rewatch the original shows, all of them. There were so many inconsistencies within the canon and gaps within it's own story.

[SPOILERS]
* When did Guinan and Picard first meet? For Guinan, it was 19th century San Francisco (in Time's Arrow). This is part of Picard's history (ST:TNG preceded ST:Picard). So it should have been more of a reunion in 2024 LA. Don't get me started on recasting the character when you have Whoopi.
* What is the origin of the name 10 Forward?  Apparently, it's from a bar in 2024.  It just happens to be the same name as the lounge located in the forward section of the 10th deck of a starship constructed many centuries later, and one that will be run by the same woman.  What a cosmic coincidence!
* What happened to Robert Picard, Jean-Luc's older brother?  He should have been somewhere in all those endless and rather pointless flashback scenes.  It would have really given the background to his resentment of Jean-Luc as seen in Season 4 of TNG.
* Why did they cast, for the role of Picard's father, an actor that looks strikingly similar to (a somewhat chunkier version of) Alexander Siddig, the actor who played Dr. Bashir on Deep Space 9, and then introduce the character as a Starfleet doctor?
* Why does every generation of Dr. Soong's look exactly the same?  (This is also a gap in Trek Canon.)  And why do these different Dr. Soong's create entities that look exactly the same?  This would be like creating something that matches exactly what one of your ancestors created back in the 17th century.
* Khan was created in the late 20th century, and yet 25 years later, he's back on the drawing board?
* Wouldn't a 21st century altruistic Borg allowed to grow for centuries have radically altered the entire Trek canon?

I could go on and on about other problems with the show (e.g., wasting the talents of Michelle Hurd and Jeri Ryan by having them bicker throughout the entire run).  This show needs to be tightened up.  It really needs its own Dave Filoni [of current Star Wars] or Kevin Fiege [Marvel].  Both men are experts on their own brands.  Both men have a firm grasp on the history of each universe (and I'm willing to forgive small infractions).  Both men know the canon.  Both men know their audiences.  I don't think that the creators of Picard understand any of that.

We also watched the first episode of Strange New Worlds, and that is showing promise.

I forced down all 10 episodes of season 2, and in all the ways I felt like TNG made me smarter, this show makes me dumber. Old Star Trek rewarded you for thinking critically. This show punishes you. The plot is nonsensical. The script is tacky--not in the campy TOS way, but more in the low-budget Sci-Fi Channel show from the mid-00s kind of way. This series is about poorly executed action, sappy emotional exchanges between characters, and trying to get the audience to say "hey I recognize that person from a different show!" In other words, the laziest kind of screenwriting.
I won't even fault Picard for not being like "old Trek." The franchise should evolve and change over time? Fine. No issues with that if that's what you think. But there's a lot of good TV out there right now, and this show is not anywhere near the same level as some of the other stuff you could be spending your time watching. But ultimately, you will watch. Why? Because Patrick Stewart is playing a guy that's ostensibly Jean-Luc Picard and you have no choice. Is this a better way for the character to go out than getting crushed by a catwalk? You decide.

At its core TNG presented the message that people have flaws and perhaps bad things happened to them or they did things in past that were not good. However, people used these experiences to become a stronger and better person. See the TNG episodes "Tapestry" and "The Inner Light." That is inspirational story telling.

Picard season 2 is just the opposite: every bad thing that happens to people makes them weaker, broken and resentful.

Then we have the woke card. Season 1 Picard was acceptable while season 2 took wokeness to a whole new level. While nothing compares to ST Discovery for woke gone amok it seems the Picard writers wanted to address their woke items. That's why the story lines and characters are so completely disjointed throughout the whole season 2:  Bring in a character and/or story line to address my woke item and then discard that thread and move onto the next woke item. 

And then there's the Borg queen assimilating all these species because she was lonely deep inside? What?? Evil people kill people for power and control over others. That is their nature.

I have been a Star Trek fan for over 25 years, and enjoy watching reruns of TOS, TNG, DS9, Voyager, and Enterprise. They never get old, and teach important lessons about acceptance, tolerance, compassion, and a myriad of other positive characteristics and attributes. I have been enjoying Discovery as well. While the first season of Picard was interesting and has some promise, moving the character of Picard forward, season 2 turned out to be a utter disaster that has permanently tarnished Star Trek and Jean-Luc Picard. What can be gleaned from the season is that Picard had a traumatic childhood and that psychology in the 24th century has apparently reverted 500 years. His father, a Starfleet Commander, locked his mentally ill mother away in a room to "help keep her from hurting herself." Picard unlocked the door and she subsequently hung herself. I guess the mild melds Picard has been through didn't dredge that memory up, huh? What a bleak future to look forward to where psychological illnesses still have devastating ramifications. Was this character growth, or character assassination? The latter seems to be more justifiable, as Jean-Luc already had deeply emotional and meaningful experiences explicated throughout all of TNG and likewise in his past. Why does Picard have to relive these experiences? Well, Q is dying and wants to take Picard on another journey through space and time to "help" him. Because that's what Q has been all about apparently, helping Picard and humanity. Gee, that Borg introduction and subsequent assimilation of Jean-Luc sure didn't seem like much help to me. The season made a mockery of Q and the plotline of him "dying alone" made absolutely zero sense. Where is the Continuum? His son? Miss Q? Nothing is explained, other than Q is lonely and wanted to see Picard because he is his "favorite." You can't make this garbage up. It would seem like a parody, if it wasn't the unfortunate reality and canonical truth. 

Oh, by the way, Wil Wheaton shows up in the last episode to whisk Kore off to become a Traveler. While his appearance and the connection established between the Travelers and Supervisors/Watchers wasn't unwelcomed, it didn't make much sense plot-wise. How did Kore merit becoming a traveler? Wil Wheaton's performance was that of giddy kid who was just happy to be there, and regrettably it shows. There was also a lost opportunity to have an interesting conversation between Q, Picard, and Traveler Crusher after Q's dramatic and doubtable explanation behind his motivations. 

The relationship between Seven and Raffi doesn't make any sense, and seems like a clear mismatch. There is no chemistry between these characters, and the straining to make a meaningful connection culminates in a kiss that is unbelievable. Seven was seen as a sex symbol on Voyager and there were calls against this sexist and stereotypic portrayal of women then. I guess she retains her sex symbol status, only now she has to appeal to the incels who love lesbians but hate gay men. The only redeeming quality to this season was the Jurati/Borg (Borgati) storyline. The Borg becoming part of the Federation is really interesting and fantastic twist to an established archenemy. 

All in all, the entire season felt as if each episode was revealing a tiny portion of the overall plot, and that little to nothing made sense or was properly explained until episode 9 or 10. The entire season can be treated as a prelude to season 3, where we will undoubtedly be subjected to continuous plot teases until the penultimate, or last, episode. Patrick Stewart needs to listen to his fans, as I'm certain he has a good deal of sway over a show named after his character. This "love letter" to Picard and Stewart is akin to the "love letter" Star Trek Enterprise was given in its finale (holographic) episode. It is an insult to Star Trek, a major blemish on Stewart's amazing acting career, and the complete character assassination of a beloved icon in sci-fi. If you're a Star Trek fan, this season will make you simultaneously sad and angry.
Loved it, some welcome returning characters and generally very enjoyable. No clue what the negative reviews are on about

Too unfocused for its own thematic ambitions! The story does not take its time for any of its themes. And there is too much unnecessary cruel and graphic scenes- not whatchable with children!

When I watched Star Trek Picard I had the impression that the story is trying to include many important themes but does not spend enough time for them and hence feels convoluted. It feels rushed and unfocused. Often I had the impression that dramatic scenes did not have sufficient setup by the story, and dialog was full of vague metaphors and truisms and the mysteries were not original and only superficially meaningful. That left the taste of shallowness. The heroes I grew up with from TOS TNG DS9 and VOY now are depicted troubled and deeply traumatized. Nevertheless, they will always remain my symbolic and idealized fix-points of measured, differentiated, tolerant, brave, positive human behavior - nobody can take this from me, not even ST Picard. Additionally there where a lot of deeply disturbing unnecessary cruel scenes. You cannot watch this show with children.
The actors do their best with what is given to them.
The art of allegorical science-fiction stories with thought provoking dilemmas that tells something about the human condition is lost in Star Trek Picard

 The story does not take its time for any of its themes. 

Themes like. Climate change, racism, totalitarianism, freedom of love, personal responsibility, exploitation and enslavement and marginalisation of social groups, migration because of war or natural catastrophies, artificial intelligence - they are all mentioned and shortly shown, but they do not become the core of the story - the themes the story is about. 

Season 2 seems to spend some time on childhood trauma and depression.
	 And yes depression can be debilitating and can occur with highly intelligent people like Rene Picard but you don't solve that with the sentence that there is always some hope and light - thats to superficial, I am sorry. I mean thats not enough to tell a story about depression. Then the Picards childhood trauma - the whole premise is that the childhood trauma makes you stuck in your past- ok but than pleas show Picard being stuck in the past. Establish and show that he can not make decisions and relationships because he always thinks about his past and is followed by it step by step. This is nether shown in TNG nor in "Picard". It is not even established in the very short scene establishing his love story. No indication. 
His love story is so shortly shown, I am sorry but there is no love story told, its just a scene showing 2 people that might have some connection and maybe some love potential but not more. 
And yes accepting who you are, and accepting your childhood trauma, process it emotionally is the key, in my opinion, but Iam sorry the story could have and should have focused more on that, because this gift by Q and that selfe revelation by Picard are the driving core of the Story. 
Why let Q create a dystopian future with galactic wide suffering? Is it really all about getting Picard hit by a car so that he falls into a coma so that a Romulan watcher can go into his mind? The whole side plots are unnecessary, so that the childhood trauma story feels rushed and does not give more than the bare minimum about that topic. And there so many unnecessarily cruel and graphic scenes in season one and two. 

I try to boil the Story down to its core to give some context for my reasoning I will not look at the abundance of story incoherences here it will be about the actual Story premises:
Warning Spoilers....!

Season 1: basically: Masseffect

1. Picard faces his Borg-trauma again, but no new character revelation given. Picard is the same. At the end it seems all Borg on the defect ship are either dead or floating in space.

2. Picard seems to feel responsible and guilty for the bad living conditions of the Romulan refugees and that he was not able to rescue all of them. But no character revelation is given to him at the end.The living conditions of the Romulan refuges did not change at the end.

3. Picard convinces the oppressed synths not to kill all intelligent biological life in the galaxy by telling them that giving biological life a chance and forgiveness is the better choice than taking revenge and committing genocide (basically a truism). The future of the synths, how they will fit into the galactic community, is not described. Picard himself becomes a synth at the end. Whether this has impact on his self-perception, his point of view, how other see him, whether he is now marginalized as well, or any implication regarding his traumatic past of being partially synthetic as a Borg - no consequence no revelation is given.

4. The secret Romulan association was basically right in their premise but act and get treated as simplistic villains - they simply disappear – no consequences no commentary on the choice of not destroying all biological life by the synths, no revelation given to the Romulans…

Season 2: A Christmas carol and the episode Tapestry from TNG 

What happens and What does Q want? 
It turns out, Q creates an nightmarish, dystopian, galaxy impacting alternate future with allot of galaxy-wide suffering so that Picard decides to time-travel into the past, so that he can get hit by a car and fall into a coma, so that a Romulan agent, that looks like the Romulan housekeeper Picard is in love with, can go into his mind and help Picard face his childhood trauma in order to accept it as a part of himself - absolve himself and tell his housekeeper about his love for her and not die alone. That is the gift Q gives Picard, because Q is dying, and he thinks alone. People die and suffer (basically the entire galaxy and the protagonists) during that story, and none of it is necessary to create that situation that Picard faces and accepts his childhood trauma. 
Q could have done it much more easy. besides- would the Borg Queen not know about Picard Trauma? It is a lost chance to make the Borg queen make picard remember and cope with his childhood trauma so that picard at the same time learns to truely forgive the borg and solve his Borg trauma aswell finally.

What impact does it have on the characters? 
Picard- It is not evident how this changes Picard – it is told but not actually shown by choices he makes. Picard was already capable to connect to people or love them or make friends before but maybe not to stay with them you could argue- is this specifically shown in "Picard"- NO- 
He decides to not prevent his own childhood trauma- but also not to prevent his mothers suicide. Regarding the role Captain Picard in TNG has in history, risking that by changing his own past would be an act of absurd selfishness for Picard, on the other hand does Picard now actually become guilty of letting his mother commit suicide knowing  that he as a grown man decided it? What is Picard take on it? This kind of dilemma, so easy to solve it seems, is not even handled by the story. Does he behave now differntly in the end? No. Does Picard being a Synth have impact on the Story (I mean the story not the plot) - NO 

Elenor: dies at the beginning and comes back to life in the end- no growth 

Raffi and 7of 9: They have a relationship with little disputes from beginning to end: no development 

Dr Jurati: she becomes more self-confident and finds a purpose in life -- kind of...But its not actually a self-revelation by the story- basically , she is brilliant but socially inhibited – so she becomes the new borg queen – is never alone again and creates an benevolent Borg collective. Ok why not. But to does this mean Picard and Seven did not get assimilated by the Borg? Or similarly: would Picard have prevented his own childhood trauma by throwing the key away? Yes or no? But that seems just symbolic for him and woud have changed nothing in his timeline. 

Captain Rios: He is Captain at the beginning - maybe a step for him? No reflection by him given. Then he falls in love and stays in the past and his doings during the rest of his life become an important part why our future becomes "good"- does he not care for the timeline or is he just assuming that his doings are ment to be? What is his revelation? He needed and wanted to care for people in a more social way and have a family- that´s good but why could he not find it in his time?

 Q- gets a hug while he is dying by Picard and therefore doesn't die alone. Q `s revelation: he is not alone because Picard is there. - Really? Thats it? (Didn't Q have a family as seen in VOY?) 

What is the moral argument about our society/human condition how I interpret the story of Picard? 

Childhood trauma can cause you to do good things but hunts you in the end and inhibits you nevertheless, so that you have to accept yourselves entirely to find peace with yourself to be able to truely connect to people. 
I don't see Picard being changed in the last episode- it is just implied that he is changed. Climate change and racism are terrible, and we will destroy our future if we don't solve them. And it depends on who solves these problems what kind of future we will have- because the story tells that if bad people solve the problem the future will be totalitarian and if good people solve the problems - the future becomes good.- The story doesn't tell about the differences of their means both seem to be connected to technology and some kind of social movement. At least thats how I interpret that storyline. 

Captain Picard, in my opinion, was never meant to be a real whole character — as the federation was never described or meant to be in detail a real possible future form of society — they are symbols playing their part in a series of allegorical stories about us. Star Trek in its core (doesn't mean it can not diverge from that formula for a while of course) is not about Picard or Q or Data or the Enterprise, Romulans .... They are all figurative symbols. The symbol of Captain Picard will always represent for me that kind of measured, differentiated, patient and decisive, intellectual, enlightened behavior I admire. The series "Picard" did not add anything for me to that. Captain Picard of TNG- Thats the symbol I look up to. 

Further Thoughts:

Classic Star Trek handles one or two themes in one episode by contrasting an idealized version of human future and idealized internally almost non-conflicted Protagonists against a symbolic/metaphorical depiction of current human problems as alien cultures or other kinds of fictional what if scenarios. The topic at hand is on one hand presented by the view of the aliens or a certain aspect of the scenario and the protagonist's idealistic view on the other hand. Because both points of views are depicted as equally strong in argumentation and validation a dilemma is described. Overall it is an Allegory of a current existing mostly social dilemma and of a measured handling of that thematic because the idealistic protagonists aim at solving the problem in dialogs and scientific measures and hold violent action as a last resort. The ideal Storyworld and main Characters do not serve as realistic depictions and do not develop and serve more like rhetorical foils for contrast and catalysts for dialog and change in the allegorical dilemma they encounter.
In later iterations of ST the allegorical dilemmas are more created using the storyworld so that a many episodes overarching season-structure of the story is possible. By this it possible to tell stories about the inherent limits of that idealized version of human future and there fore making the protagonists more human with weaknesses, wants and needs themselves rather then the aliens or the what if situation. This development in ST mirrors the overall development in TV/streaming series to an overarching structure (GOTH, BB), unfortunately ST did not wholeheartedly implement the overarching story-structure that become popular.
The Reboot era of ST marks a total shift towards that structure. Story world and protagonists are not anymore depicted as idealized, idealistic, internally non-conflicted and barely developing to not idealized, mostly non-idealistic, and in almost every case internally deeply conflicted. The problem lays in the development of the characters and the story-world. In order for character and world development, the protagonists have to make character revealing decisions, the more difficult the more revealing. In order to do that the depiction of their struggle with the given dilemma and of course, the dilemma itself has to be shown by the story. Unfortunately, the given problems are mostly described in exposition and less shown and foremost in unequal depiction hence the ambiguous nature of the problem- hence a dilemma is not shown. Problems are solved without real inconveniences for the characters and predominantly by simple overpowering of the obstacle. It is a shift from an allegorical story focusing on the depiction of a dilemma as the core of that story to plot focusing on fast and conveniently easy overcoming of action heavy obstacles and just mentioning themes by exposition or by far too short situations, hence decisions and therefore actions do not serve a function in the story-structure but rather as necessary for the plot. Therefore seemingly difficult decisions do not feel deeply revealing because the situation is not organically developed and depicted in a differentiated way but just enabled. Without deeply felt revealing decisions the depicted character developments seem shallow and forced to just happen, despite the dramatic dialog and acting that give their best to make believe that you are watching a story-driven drama that handles relevant current topics -  instead of what is actually happening: a convoluted unfocused story trying to include all today's relevant topics but giving none of them the time or differentiated handling they need and deserve. Many dramatic situations appear without necessary setup and mystery setups without original payoffs. Where classic ST characters were by story-design two-dimensional to serve their function in the allegory, reboot ST characters, the ones that existed before and the new ones, all get traumatic/abusive backgrounds with guilt and addictions and hence denying in hind-side their rhetorical function as fictional symbols of the idealized human potential of every individual human and society, and therefore their function as positive symbolic fix-points in a broader narrative sense and on a very personal level for many classic ST fans. Where lassic ST stood out as a positive, utopian and you might say naive approach to the future when all other where rather dystopian, thus giving a unique comment in the frame of discussing the future, reboot ST follows the trends made by others denies that or any other original approach. Where classic ST is watchable with the entire family, reboot ST is filled with disturbing unnecessarily directly graphically depicted cruel and brutal scenes. Where classic ST presented often preachy arguments but thought provoking dilemmas aswell, reboot ST presents truisms and vague metaphors and still preachy arguments. Where classic ST focuses on a wide range of aspects of the human condition and in its capacity as science-fiction often on the relation between humans and technology in an allegorical and mostly episodic way in the core of the story, the ST Reboot claims to handle a lot but focuses on nothing.

Thanks for reading!

A brilliant season that was both deeply insightful as a character study (Picard as a damaged soul) and in the grander societal concepts (wealth/class division in the near future with potential fascist implications). Unfortunately, both of these can be very touchy issues for many people who will feel defensive a great man they admire being shown to also be broken or who want to turn a blind eye to the social issues of the day and seek distraction from them rather than engagement in a conversation about them. Throw in a small amount of non-majority representation and you can imagine how the fragile egos are going to rant and rave and rail against any and every aspect of the show, which can distract from the brilliance I mentioned at the beginning of this review. My advice: if you're a Trek fan, particularly a fan of Picard as a character, then binge the show, get your thoughts together about it, and come leave a review yourself before you read a single other opinion (not that mine should be the last by any merit, but unlike Picard I can't turn back time and here we are). On the otherhand, if you're just sick of "woke culture", or something like that, you might just want to move on to whatever the goongeist decides it's next target is going to be since you're pretty late to the party here. We'll sadly be seeing you for season 3 soon enough.
Well written and well acted. We are seeing a Renaissance of great Star Trek and this show is leading the way.

The backstory of Picard and his Mom so unnecessary and boring, and you have ruined the image of Captain Picard, painting him as some kind of man with a terrible childhood with a horrible Father, ridiculous! Its one sappy scene after another with sappy music! WHY DO YOU HATE Straight MEN!!!! Straight MEN ARENT BAD and we love Star Trek and its ideals! I feel completely excluded from Star Trek

Of course, I understand that many seek instant and unconditional gratification that requires no intellectual effort, and that is of course normal these days. Nevertheless, I can totally recommend this series and eagerly anticipate Season 3. Make it so!

All modern Star Trek is garbage, but this one is the worst of the lot. Unforgivable, rotten to the core, space garbage!

I just finished watching the season 2 finale of Star Trek: Picard, ‘Farewell' -- the writing, the story, the people, the themes -- are so great it has renewed my faith in the human race and our future, together -- we have hope.  I'm an AGI researcher and a Human Rights ambassador for the United Nations Council of Organizations(AUI)-- and CEO/Chief Scientist of a Foundation for the Protection of Constitutional Rights--I cannot commend more highly the insight, inspiration, aspirations, foreboding/forewarning -- and hope -- that such great works of art, --such as Star Trek--, always have and always will continue to astonish and astound us and remind of what it means to be human, and the great path that lies before us.

Wow!  Lots of haters here.  I am a longtime fan of the show going back to TOS - and was in a star trek club in the 70's.  I found this season of Picard really enjoyable and looked forward to the episodes every week.  The Serialized format is a bit different than the prior episodic one - but I enjoyed that it included Q, Guinan, the Borg and time travel. I find the characters interesting, and appreciate that they have flaws and struggle with various things.  Star trek has always had plot holes and inconsistencies, and often some complex situation tied up just a little too neatly at the end of an episode.  I don't care!  It can be a bit preachy at times - but that goes back to the beginning of Star Trek, and Roddenberry openly spoke about being able to address issues of the day by placing it in a Sci-fi setting, that would not have gotten past the TV Censors of the 60's.  To me, it's enjoyable and worth the watch.

How could the executives of this show get it so wrong? This series is incompatible with Star Trek.

It amplifies everything that's wrong with cashgrab reboots/sequels with a complete disconnect from the target audience.  "Star Trek": Picard is low brow fan fiction created and produced by people who should never have been given access to this show or the original actors. It's a gross miscalculation of the audience's expectation that has resulted in actualised damage to the brand as fans just give up and walk away, not just from this series, but from the franchise as a whole. It's insulting to the target audience's intelligence that the showrunners believed this would be acceptable, much less to be praised for their incompetence. 
It's artistic presentation is completely unremarkable with none of the hallmarks of Star Trek. Instead the viewer is presented with run of the mill bad Sci-Fi that neither has any link to science, or believable fiction. 
The characters are frustratingly unbelievable and poorly written, making childish behavioural decisions which break the fourth wall with their stupidity. It's abundantly clear that the writers and producers have told the Star Trek alumni cast to completely alter their characters to such disastrous extent that they bear no resemblance whatsoever to the characters they claim to be beyond the actor's faces. 
Not a scene goes by that doesn't invoke a facepalm of despair when the viewer is reminded they are more intelligent and knowledgeable than the writers and producers. "Star Trek" Picard has made it very clear to me that it's absolutely possible to fall out of love with something that previously felt it would last a lifetime. 

You've killed Star Trek for me, and from what I can tell I'm in the majority. In fact, I don't know of anyone who has seen this "Star Trek" Picard production as anything other than catastrophic to their enjoyment of everything that came before. TNG and "Star Trek" Picard are completely incompatible, one can only try to enjoy TNG again by amputating this shambolic mockery from memory, but it can not be unseen.

This show was clearly written and acted by people who are not fans of Star Trek. So ignoring their ignorance and disdain toward the franchise I'll review the show as if it were a standalone original series.

Characters are unlikeable. They aren't written realistically and it feels like every character needs to have some kind of poorly thought out traumatic backstory. Nothing ever resolves in a satisfying manner. Relationships are unrealistic, forced, and seem to exist more to fit a quota than to enrich the character's existence. 

Plot holes abound. Story arcs are poorly thought out and almost always end poorly. Too often plot points seem to exist simply to make us the audience like the characters. Having a character do things to solve issues invented simply for the characters to solve isn't how you make a character likable but someone clearly hasn't told the writers of this show that.

I'd give the show a 0/10 in every category. Absolutely a waste of time.
A real visit into aging heros and why they remain heros.

Well…the first season of Picard gave me hope, but season 2 was trash.

I am going to give some spoilers here, so stop reading if you want to watch a lousy show without foreknowledge of its "plot."

This season just wandered way too much.  Why are we just now learning of Picard's mommy's suicide?  Why was it really essential to this story (it isn't)?  Traveling back in time yet again.  Okay, maybe that can work…I enjoyed Star Trek IV after all….but this…another chance to fondle all of the woke generation's touchstones.  I want to escape today's political strife while watching entertainment, not get mired in it.  Star Trek dealt with current issues before, but often in a more subtle, or imaginative way (for exampl, Let That be Your Last Battlefield in the original series)…this season of Picard just hits you with a woke hammer.  Why are we just now learning about Picard's famous ancestor whose discoveries saved us all from climate change?  How is the Borg able to be reasoned with and so easily accept goody two shoes approach to changing their raison d'etre?  Q seemed very important and interesting early in the season, but only showed up again at the end to put a bow on this dumpster fire of a story….  Oh…and get this….season 3 likely will bring us yet another return of Khan.  Please, dear God, think of something original.  There was so much crying, hand-wringing, sniveling in this show by characters who used to be heroic in nature.  Yet, when the time comes, they dish out violence without their emotions getting in the way.  The final episode was just horrible.  It was on par with Star Wars 9…fan service and trying to undo the mess they wove like a terd tapestry from episode 3-9.  I liked Enterprise and even liked the first two JJ Trek movies, but man…stop ruining one of my favorite franchises.

Star Trek has been dead a loooooong time. This is just Kurtzman and his "writers" defecating on the rotting corpse, perhaps out of spite at better showrunners/writers, but more probably because it is all they are capable of doing…

Honestly, whoever wrote this should be embarrassed. It started out OK but by episode 3 was a mess and then pretty much nothing related to the initial plot thread happens until episode 9. The writing is just awful, like a soap opera, much worse than season 1. The show is superficially Star Trek. It has the actors, ships, aliens, etc but the characters don't behave like themselves and it's missing the message of hope for the future, showing what humanity could become. Instead these humans from the future have the same problems (or worse than we do). Everyone has had massive tragedy in their live that motivates who they become. It's basically a poorly written action movies with Star Trek intellectual property.
Too many weak subplots that take away from the main plot which needed more depth.  Overall disappointing.  Hope season 3 is better.

Possibly the worst Star Trek season in all of Star Trek's history.
The writing is simply very, very lazy. They have no regard for what came before - and I don't always mean in canon. They even contradict things in previous episodes.

What started off with a fun 3 episodes turned into a boring slog with horrible character interactions and pointless scenes.

All I can say is if you're not enjoying this season or just don't like it at all you need to watch the original series episode Assignment: Earth and ALL of The Next Generation. 

If you still don't get it then Star Trek isn't for you.

My most anticipated show in a long long time. It was pretty bad. The officers from the other star trek shows attempted to act like... Well... Officers. They were trained and acted with intention. This entire version of starfleet and every character is rash and impulsive and selfish. It's like watching a 27 year old guy who didn't mature beyond his frat days pretend he was a star fleet officer. It's very strange. .  I know much has been made of the language but it seems like that is purely a problem stemming from the type of person who is written. A adult adolescent.  Even beyond the tone of the characters there are so many off issues. Like just head scratching moments.
Characters introduced who do not act in any sort of consistent manner. 
There are several points in the second season that just blatantly contradict the first season for instance a former Borg character says that they were not allowed to join starfleet because they were former Borg. But... That's after being introduced to a Borg, who clearly was in star fleet hence the uniform, in the first season. 

Or things like ancestors or descendants looking exactly like their eventual grandchildren/grandparents.
 Which... Is fine I guess.  But when they go out of their way to show that previous character dying or being able to have kids etc etc... So ... How could they have had kids? They died so they wouldn't have had descendants and that was after stating they had been doing this one thing for their entire life. It's that sort of thing. It's not exactly knit picking because it's everywhere. Like walking barefoot on Lego's Just lots of inconveniences . And thats ignoring the retconning that's done for all our characters. Such as Picard apparently never having a love story before ... When he did?   I think B Crusher would be pretty upset to hear that.

Or him having no idea what it was like to have kids? When he had the experiences of an entire life with a wife and children on tng. And that's a very character defining moment on that show.  Like that episode grows the character. Also I think they forgot that Picard had a brother. Or that his father was also bald?  It's just... Like... I don't understand. These aren't super deep cuts. But basic continuity issues.  
...
It's very odd is the best I can say. It's like watching Babylon 5 or any other random sci-fi show except it is set in star trek clothes. But it doesn't act like start trek. These aren't more civilized or any better than today. In fact there is lots of poverty and drug addiction and crime and everything else that the other shows specifically said they had gotten rid of. . 
Oh and vaccines. Yes vaccines get brought up. How they have vaccine chips. And identity chips. ...
So... What? Wait now in the future we haven't gotten rid of these things but rather everyone is chipped like a dog? Ugh. It's just so strange. . 
I've not disliked a show is such a long time. And worst of all I was really ready to accept even mediocre work. But this makes enterprise looks like a brilliant show. Which... Is sad

How do critics give this show a good score? Words cannot describe the problems with this show. Writing is egregious, graphics are horrendous, and any reference to old Trek has been destroyed. There is nothing Star Trek about this series. Characters that are supposed to exist 500 years in the future talk how we do today and drop an F-Bomb every other word. Picard isn't Picard. Rather just Patrick Stewart hanging out on camera (not even acting). One of Star Trek's most dangerous villains turn out to just be "lonely"? I can't even begin to comprehend this dumpster fire of a show. Biggest middle finger to anyone wanting to watch Star Trek.

The five stages of grief– denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance.
I now accept that Star Trek is dead. Something I cherished and taught me a lot about the world has been obliterated. It started to go off the rails in 2009, and I have given it way more latitude to course correct, but I just can't do it anymore. It's like seeing someone you love in their final moments delirious as they fade away into nothing not with a bang, but with a whimper through chronic mismanagement having driven it into the dirt. I'm walking away from this abusive relationship CBS and Paramount have toward Star Trek fans and moving on with my life.

CBS and Paramount have done something I never even considered possible before - new Star Trek has effected my enjoyment of everything that came before these reboots, and I am simply done. It's dead and I've moved on.  The end.

It's just not Star Trek! There's no hopeful future here, it's a dark boring generic sci-fi. You cant watch it with your kids for all the swearing every two seconds. Plot holes emerge every two minutes and the whole story is just boring its really not enjoyable.

Alex Kurtzman should be procecuted for elder abuse. I'm not even joking. He seemingly didn't care about a great actors legacy, he only apparently cared about telling shareholders they were making a Picard series to stave off their fury at what a dogs dinner flop STD turned out to be. He doesn't seem to have cared if the great actor had lost his critical faculties, he apparently allowed anything to be filmed that would get the signature on a piece of paper. He knew the usual nodding dog critics would nod it through rotten tomatoes as long as he included 'the right' messaging and as long as he did it regularly enough and bluntly enough that it could be picked up while the critics were watching their review copies on fast forward. Alex Kurtzman should be procecuted for elder abuse.
Dumb enough to be a crime. Pretentious enough to be a crime. This is a double-homicide of my childhood and my hope for the future.
Please stop letting Alex Kurtzman near Star Trek.

I sincerely didn't think it possible that Star Trek: Picard could surpass the dismal writing from season one, but here we are. It cannot be overstated how terrible the writing is on season two of this show. Don't be fooled by reviews from critics that never actually watch more than a couple episodes before posting on this site and others. The reality is that Star Trek: Picard is not merely the worst iteration of a once-beloved franchise, but it may well be the worst written television show I've ever seen of any kind, period. It is an unmitigated disaster, and Alex Kurtzman, Akiva Goldsman, and Terry Matalas should never again be allowed to work on this franchise.

It is even worst than STD!
They ruined my favorite Star Trek character and my favorite villains.

This is, quite frankly, some of the worst television I've ever watched in my life.

It's telling how all of the professional reviews that rave about the show were back when only the first episode had been released - the first episode was pretty strong, after that it devolved into absolute nonsense.

There are a lot of complaints about respecting the history of Star Trek, and that's on thing, but this show doesn't even respect its own occurrences. Characters not only don't act like the legacy characters they are meant to be, but they also act inconsistently with their own motivations from one scene to the next. I get that you have to suspend disbelief for a show about humanoid aliens and teleportation and FTL travel, but it's not even just the Sci-Fi elements that they fudge - there are so many moments in this that you can just blatantly look at and say "that could and would never happen".

The fact that one of the big problems faced by the crew this season was not to pollute the timeline is laughable when you see the absolute carnage they wreak. Exposition dumps aplenty (if Picard mentions "Kirk's Enterprise" one more time I think I'll throw up - it's like he watched the Original Star Trek series along with us), I genuinely don't know who this show is supposed to be for - there are too many callbacks for newcomers to get half of what is going on, but it's got none of classic Trek's soul and ethos and is roundly derided by classic fans. It's just simply nonsense.

This actually might be the final nail in the coffin for Star Trek as a franchise going forward, if we ever expect to see any sort of return to quality. The only way that this train-wreck could be put right is if they were to pull a Dallas dream ending and erase it from ever happening. It makes a mockery of all that has come before it.
This is a show written by the creatively bankrupt for people whose only personal standard for their own entertainment is the brand name associated with it.

Started off strong but got bogged down with poor pacing, then took a nosedive in episode 9.  Most of the characters' motivations became unconvincing, particularly a specific villian's sudden change of heart.  Picard does not feel like the same character from the classic TV show, with even his classic speeches reduced to lots of cliches.  The show's only redeeming quality is Hansen as Seven - great acting, and at least somewhat interesting writing.

I literally created my account to express my distaste for this.  This is NOT Star Trek.  I don't know what has happened to Gene's vision but it's dead.  Its been destroyed by Kurtzman.  Just...RUINED.

It's better than Season One.  However S1 set such a low bar that this wasn't hard.

Season Two got off to such a great start - the first two episodes were great.  But they made the same plot errors in Picard that they did in Season Four of Discovery: in Discovery they touted a new alien species, then spent around eight episodes of filler before we meet them.  In Picard they have spent the entire series focussed on a forthcoming event, and the entire series has now become so slow and mired down that I really couldn't care what happens in the finale.

This is bad, bad writing.  And it does the future of Star Trek a major disservice:  if both Picard and Discovery are so poorly received then Paramount will be chary about greenlighting new series henceforth.
Sadly season is very dull with lots of flashbacks to piccards childhood which serve as nothing but padding
Slow burning, so if you like crash bang pew pew telly, probably give this a miss. Masterful in long form story telling with an unhurried plot and outstanding actors.

I had a nice long essay explaining my rationale, but that mysteriously vanished...so you will just have to take my word for it that this season reminds me of a hot fudge sundae made out of sh*t. You can add whip cream and even put a cherry on top... it may look appetizing for a split second, but you know it's sh*t. Then trolls try to convince you it's chocolate just because it's brown.
Ok, but frustrating and too many side stories that do not add to the plot very much. I am sticking with it but feeIs padded.

It costs $250 000 to educate a good writer in the US. Patrick Stewart and Kurtzman's writer wouldn't even qualify for a $250 000 home loan if they all banded together.
With most qualifications seeming to be "I read the Hunger Games and cried."

It's depressing when characters use simple metaphors incorrectly. Don't understand basic science terms. But, what is worse is that there is not continuity.   

Not just between old and "new" Trek but even between season one and two. 

Character development is bizarre and erratic.
