I like the Spanish Captain but can't even remember his name so it can't be that much.
All the other characters seem to just be there to generate drama and conflict. Which is not what Star Trek fans want from Star Trek. That's Battlestar.  

I used to say if you do nothing else as a parent make your kid watch Star Trek and they'll turn out alright. I can't say that any more.

If you show a kid this they'll think murder is fine if you are sad about it. They will think that rules are for other people. They will think that they can solve any problems by shouting about their feeling at violent strangers.

There is also no science in this show. Clearly, there was no money. It all takes place in 2024, a year we have seen in Trek before - but they ignore this, and it just looks like 2022 without the masks.

It's lazy, it's sad, and what it has to say is clumsy.    

For example: It tries to make a commentary on migration or policing or racism or all of these at once. And it's only solution to this is violence. 

This show love fighting it love murder. It hates dialogue and reasoning and diplomacy. 

In essence it teaches that to defeat evil you must kill all the "evil" people. Which seems like something the Germans though was a good idea in the past in real life.

To quote Krayshon from Lower Deck this show makes me feel "Zinda his eyes red" and has been a colosal "Shaka when the walls fell"

This is a lesson about why people should retire while they are ahead.

This is such a poor season. The worst part of this whole season so far are these flashbacks to young Picard that interrupt the story every 10-15 minutes, which doesn't really pay off until episode 9. Even by then, it feels like it REALLY didn't need to be hammered into the story that much. 

!!!SPOILER!!!
Also, what the hell is with siding with the borg queen and making her see reason? She came around to the idea way too easily that didn't really seem very borg like.

Very disappointed.  The plot stumbles through labyrinths of back stories that are irrelevant and painful.  You can almost see the writer struggling to fill the page.  Meanwhile, the Borg Queen plays Agent Smith and occupies Jurati.  No explanation is provided.  Then she plays gollum and argues with herself.  Then she plays Harry Potter and performs magic - creating nano-probes from inside a human body by sucking on battery acid.  The characters are very compelling and the nostalgia of seeing Picard and Seven in action is rewarding.  And of course Brent Spiner is always welcome.  However, Dr. Soong has devolved into an Evil Geneticist??  Suspending belief with "Picard" this season takes some heavy lifting.

Writers need to stop "categorizing" their audience and warping the plot to appeal to specific audiences. It doesn't make any sense and severely degrades the storyline.

Having the latino crewmember be deported by ICE is the cringe-iest thing I've ever watched. Just keep the politics out of it please.

The FBI shows up with like a dozen agents, arrests Picard and Guinan, and they have video footage of Picard beaming in out of nowhere... so they seize Picard's (future tech) badge, start interrogating him..... suddenly Picard asks him "why did you become an FBI agent" and the interrogator explains how he was visited by Vulcans as a child... next scene, the FBI  suddenly lets him go because "the interrogator got fired for reporting aliens"? ... then 10 minutes later, the interrogator comes back with all his desk's stuff (as he's leaving the building)??? Is the audience is 6 years old? This is ridiculous.

also - why would they have Picard approaching his ancestor, alone in a hallway, and chatting her up? That's super weird and creepy. Old men who are strangers should not chat up young drunk women. Massively creepy and weird that they would include that in the show.

The whole thing with Soong's daughter is really confusing. Because when you have a daughter who's a grown woman now, and you're apparently a genius geneticist, surely you might explain to her at some point what kind of work you're doing? She's apparently home all day and has no friends, therefore probably gets most of her "family values" from Soong. And so it's just really confusing why she'd be so upset that she'd run away the instant she finds out as a baby she was grown in a lab. This is a very complicated ethical situation and they threw it together just to show her running away from Soong when he's "evil" for growing her as a baby? All that for what?

But the plot holes just go on and on. Borg queen going around eating car batteries because she wants lithium? That is really weird and doesn't make sense. But also: car batteries are made from lead and sulfuric acid.

The action scenes in episode 9 at the chateau were shockingly bad. Also: why are the borg soldiers using their gun's laser sight to look through windows?

Speaking of the borg soldiers - how did Soong somehow summon a few dozen soldiers out of nowhere? And how did they not resist as they were turned into borg one by one?

I guess I kept watching because I just wanted to see how they were going to tie it all together. I had hope in the beginning but at this point I'm wondering how I got interested in this show at all.
The writers owe Patrick Stewart an apology...all of us an apology.

Spoilers* As a lifelong trekkie who has seen every episode of every series 5 times at least, I find this show an absolute insult to everything named Star Trek. And I am incredibly confused on why the critics rate this so high, maybe they did their reviews after only the first episode?

I have but four things to mention about season two:

1) The borg, who are only motivated by biological and technological perfection are now friendly bottom feeders destined to only assimilate the losers of the galaxy.

2) Seven and Raffi can run 50 feet across an open field armed with nothing but a crusty knife and survive against trained borg enhanced mercenaries

3) Two episodes of vilifying ICE, just because the original Star Treks had noble goals like putting the first black and female people in the captains seat doesn't mean we need to push our political agenda on everyone.

4) When did star trek become a musical drama with 300 subplots in every episode?

I seriously can't express to you how stupid the thing with the borg is, of all the billions of people that have faced the Borg, the one to change their mind about their entire motivation to exist is the WORST character in star trek to ever exist (Raffi is close behind) And we are NOT talking an epic Anakin to the darkside transition either, Imagine you take the Borg Queen to starbucks and you simply say "Why don't you just try ASKING people to be assimilated" And the Borg queens reply is literally "Wow I never thought of it that way you are so smart" Pathetic garbage, I have never reviewed a piece of cinema in my entire life. I honestly don't know that I can watch TNG anymore as I will just remember that they ruined it all here.

People love Patrick Stewart as Picard, but I could never dream a worse show than Picard. Picard is a textbook example of how to misuse talent, misuse a storied template and how to make dedicated followers loose interest. Season two will rank poorly in the junkyard heap of supposed "sci-fi" shows.

I am a trekkie and loved every show when it came out except "Discovery" but that show has greatly improved. "Picard" is unlovable and unfixable (that's probably why the next season will be the last). This show is so poorly written, it hurts. Plot (doom and gloom because it's fun to shoot and kill) and character development make no sense (Picard, famous for his inspiring speeches, can't find anything to say and shoots around like a B movie character to distract the audience. Can you imagine the great scene that could have been with an ironic Picard speech "I am here to give you what you deserve!."), clichés galore (Hey, woman shooting "like a man" with the biggest gun she could find. How new! How rare! Equality in idiocy, yeah. Clearly the ideal man must be a cowboy), no trace of Star Trek values and vision (optimistic view of the future, diplomacy, philosophy), gratuitious violence (shoot first, ask later), absurd elements (why not use phasers - on stunt - instead of old fashioned weapons?), pointless special effects (oh look now they beam into/from a cloud). This show is nevertheless useful: it can be studied in film schools as an example never ever to follow.
I feel sorry for the fine actors lost in this heart of filmmaking darkness.

This should not be called star trek, it is an affront of everything that star trek stood for. Season 1 was bad but this has gone to even lower depth of trash. The fight scenes make no sense, random Picard flashbacks are repetitive and dull and of course they get all the star trek lore wrong.

Star Trek, the once great franchise spanning 5 decades, has been hacked apart by bad writing and turning beloved characters into pathetic, tragic and irrelevant plot devices to fan bait true Trekkies that fell in love with Roddenberry's lore about an optimistic future for humanity. Picard season 2 hits a new low by being farcical and disrespectful to the established lore. When episode 9 could not get any worse, the writers just had to destroy all established lore regarding the Borg. I will not be watching Picard season 3 as the writers seem determined to kill long time fans' love of TNG. I shudder to think how the current writers will deconstruct Worf, La Forge, Beverly and the rest.

Dreadful. I'm on episode 9 and seems to get slower and worse with each new episode. The first couple were adequate if slow paced but since going back in time we've seen ponderous plot lines and an enfeebled team stumble about aimlessly for hour after hour each battling their inner demons and angst in a pathetically 2022 fashion. The sooner it's over the better.

The first season was pretty good  and enjoyable, even though the underlying optimistic Star Trek message, characteristic to all older shows was gone, which is unnerving to say the least. Season 2 howewer borders on the unwatchable. Episode 9 was the epitome of incompetence of pretty much everyone involved. People can't shoot right, not even trained Rangers or Starfleet officers and their particle weapons are pathetic, throwing stones would be better. We're supposed to believe that, in an active shooting situation, Picard, who's the very definition of calm and composure, has (very slow moving) emotional flashbacks concerning his mentality ill late mother. We're setting aside the fact he has no older brother anymore, we're simply supposed to swallow the notion that years of Starfleet training, plus hands on experience commanding Federation's flagship thru the trickiest and most complicated situations possible, including being assimilated by the Borg won't matter anymore because Picard is blaming himself for Mommy's suicide. Then we have Jurati convincing the Borg Queen to give Democracy a chance quicker than any falling meteor. In fact I've seen slower falling meteors. This season gave vivid Game of Thrones last Season flashbacks, only the writing here somehow manages the rather difficult task of actually being worse. I would give this season a negative rating if I could.

The first season really was very good. Loved it. 

This second season is unbelievably bad... Terrible writing and dialogue. Very unlikeable secondary characters, and the bizarre choice to use time travel to plunk the characters in the middle of one of the most unimaginative uninspiring and boring places on earth. Las Angeles city present day. How is that interesting sci-fi? I watch sci-fi because it's a feel good fun ESCAPE from the blah of life. What is this? Star Trek CSI LA? What dreck.

I love star trek TNG! One of the all time best prime time shows ever made IMO. 

This show better have a warp 10 season 3 or they have totally wrecked the series. Get back to the sci-fi. Try something new! Don't do lazy trash time travel to present day. Uber lame.
Awful and artificial dialogues beneath the actors involved, no character development. Just bad.

I don't even know where to start.

"Star Trek: Picard" isn't just the worst thing to ever be called "Star Trek," it's possibly the worst renewed television production of the century.

This show is a meandering, low brow, hyperviolent, poorly produced melodrama with a cast of drug addicted, alcoholic, sociopathic, serial murderers who wield endless, exhausting, sarcasm in place of intellect or mutual respect.

"Raffi," specifically, stands out as the personification of Kurtzman Trek; dumb, violent, needlessly sarcastic, with no character development or arc, and no motivations outside of her own selfish agenda. I watched as her pet space elf slit the throats of 4 officers and all she did was make jokes.
That's not to say the other characters are much better. They're not.
Seven used to be arguably the smartest character in all of Star Trek. Now? She's been relegated to the role of a beauty queen who can't do basic math, a character who's only purpose seems to be murdering people and making boozey one-liners.
And what about the titular character? Picard? His sole purpose seems to be getting talked down to by everyone around him. That is, when he's not giving the Borg Queen a front row seat to Earth's past.

I wish I could just blame Alex Kurtzman but it's not just him. These writers; Goldsman and Chabon and co are maybe the worst writers working in the industry today. 

If Paramount/CBS had *any* sense they'd do one of two things:
1) Fire Alex Kurtzman + every writer on Picard and hand control of the franchise to Mike Mcmahan(sp?) who is infinitely more familiar with the material and values of Star Trek.
2) Beg, plead, pay Ronald D. Moore anything he asks for him to assemble a writers room and pen season 3.

Because the world needs a bright, hopeful, optimistic vision of the future right now.
We do not need more of this poorly connected tale of meandering misery.

You know what Kurtzman Trek is like?
It's like Halloween and you've got a big costume party to attend... but you don't have a costume. So on your way to the party you stop at a drug store to buy a costume. You really want to be Iron Man but all the drug store has is "Metal Hero Friend" -- that's kurtzman trek.

I think the major failing with season 2 is that after the success of season one, they tried to do too much. There's so much going on and so much hopping around that you can't decide who or what is important and what to follow.
That and they did the time travel thing which has been a bit done to death. 
I'm still watching to see how it wraps up, but I thing it could have been simplified a lot and had a greater impact.

I consider this show so bad that it's not in canon with any pre-2009 Star Trek to be honest.

The Kurtzman years are easily the worst of Star Trek, so much so that it's Star Trek in name only.

I don't think the writers have a clue what Star Trek is about.  Rather than a hopeful, optimistic future everything has to be dark, violent and depressing.  Worse than that, the writers can't even do *that* well - there are so many plot threads picked up and dropped it's ridiculous.  Season 1 did it and Season 2 continues it.  Discovery has the same problem; it's often wishy-washy soap opera with these would-be big emotional moments that have absolutely zero impact because the show is all over the place and really doesn't make a lot of sense.

This time around they're pillaging Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home, you know, the one with the whales as it's often referred to?  Except as usual they steal the premise, fail to understand what made it work originally.  Perhaps they should all go back to school and learn, or at the very least have the idea for the finale and then work backwards from there like a murder mystery author might, instead of flailing around writing terrible dialogue for a bunch of horrible, unlikeable characters who, funnily enough, are often cold-blooded murderers (looking at you, Seven of Nine).

Don't believe any critic reviews who certify this as fresh - as with the Twitter hype it's probably CBS/Paramount paying people off to polish this turd.  It's even more shameful that Will Wheaton is shilling for this abomination as if that gives it more credibility - it doesn't.

All things considered it's one of the worst TV shows I've ever seen as it doesn't only ruin Star Trek as a concept, it demonstrates time and again what bad writing looks like.  I haven't mentioned Patrick Stewart yet, so I will - he's not Captain Picard.  Like the show, it's Picard in name only.  The authoritative, brilliant, diplomatic, "violence as a last resort only" character is dead and buried.  There's just a hollow old man collecting a pay cheque left, browbeaten by drug-addled, troubled and mystifyingly unbalanced female characters (because apparently that's how you write "strong" female characters these days, rather than, I don't know, in the style of Sarah Connor from the first two Terminator movies as a driven, passionate badass who only bends the rules for the good of humanity) and what can laughably be called the plot is such drivel it's hard to care.  They even managed to waste John DeLancie's talents as the usually highly entertaining omnipotent trickster Q - like all the rest, he's just dark and depressed and dare I say it, boring.  I suppose him and all the other TNG cast members were offered a pay day too good to resist, and in doing so help ruin the legacy of Star Trek in the process.

I don't blame them though; as Mike Stoklasa said in character as Harry S. Plinkett, "new boats aren't gonna buy themselves."
Todo excelente EXCEPTO EL GUION... ES IMPRESENTABLE.

I grew up watching Star Trek - I've seen every episode of every series 10 times.  This show, and especially this season, has completely ruined Star Trek for me.  What an absolute hunk of garbage.  The writing is so painfully bad.  They've ruined the most beloved character in Star Trek history.  Just when you think it can't get any worse, a new episode comes out and blows the last one out of the water with its plot holes and clichés.  I am not just disappointed - I am livid.  They had a golden opportunity to send Picard and Patrick Stewart out in style.  Now he'll be remembered for this trash.  It makes me sad. I honestly wish I'd never watched this show so I could remember Picard the way he was meant to be remembered.  This may have put me off Star Trek for good.  Shame on the writers.

After a really great season one, season two of Picard is abysmal. The writing, the storyline, even the acting is a complete 180 from what we experienced in season one. This could be fall out from the pandemic but if that's the case it probably should not have moved forward with season two in this way. Totally disappointed and paramount plus should be ashamed of themselves for doing this to Star Trek and for putting sir Patrick Stewart in this insulting situation.

Is ruining beloved characters the new fetish of Hollywood? What happened? What are the so called "critics" smoking? And not just that. This show fails in almost every metric possible. The poor writing, phasing, character development or should I say deterioration. Everything is mediocre. Even the FX. A Microsoft Hololens? Hundreds of years in the future? C'mon.

Season 2 started of strong with an interresting mystery, great visuals and finally some Star Trek-like vibe. After that however, it just became the same mess we've seen in all seasons of Discovery and the previous season of Picard: slow pased, very uninterresting or borderline annoying characters and a complete lack of consistency or logic. To me, the writers are just completely incompetent with the material they are dealing with. It's all over the place. It's so bad that season 3 is comfirmed during a running seasons and in season 3 they are appealing to the nostalgia by bringing back all the old characters from TNG. The only thing I feel by that is: ah great, more characters they can screw up. Visually the series looks great though, I'll give them that. I completely stopped watching Discovery after season 3 because I just didn't care anymore. I'm not there yet with Picard, but we're getting closer to that point.

Edit: just saw episode 9 and changed the score from 1 star to 0,5. I wish it could go lower than 0,5. It's the end of Star Trek and it's never going to recover.
It's bad. See all the other bad reviews to understand why.

I understand why "maman" killed herself... it was her only way to escape this abomination of a world created by Alex Kurtzman and the rest of his crew. I would not want to live in a world of senseless dialogue, poor writing and everything else these so-called producers can be so proud of.

How bad can Trek writers get? I thought they had hit bottom with Discovery, but ST:Picard takes incompetence to whole new depths. I've lost track of the go-nowhere plots ("We need some drama, let's have _____ (character) get _______ (hurt or arrested"). Even the cops have psychological trauma that we need to see in flashback. Flashbacks that retcon Vulcan First Contact. Really? I'm waiting for the Borg Queen to get injured and need to go to the clinic for a psychiatric mind probe before being arrested. Oh, wait, she already did get injured and have a mind probe. She just needs to get cuffed and interrogated by police while philosophizing about climate change and homelessness. I think they've spent more of this season inside everyone's dark minds than anywhere else.

What can I say that hasn't been said?  I get the good pro reviews as they were mostly done after first episode or two.  Hey I thought the first couple of episodes were good, but man, Left turn Clyde, we're going to 2024 LA.  Total load of rubbish, confusing, boring, nonsensical, moronic.  I don't think the writers ever watched a Star Trek episode.  Probably same geniuses who wrote Discovery.  This show is dead to me.

I enjoyed the first season. This season started off with an interesting premise but soon started to drag and feel lacklustre. 
I honestly can't be bothered to spend more time watching this watered-down plot. If you enjoy this season then that is excellent! For me, I just felt really bored near the midseason mark. Shame really, as time travel is a really neat plot point to explore.
Patrick Stewart is awesome as always, but the script is poor.  too much fluff to fill out the episodes... not enough good writing and good sci-fi.
Season 2 starts with great promise, seemingly correcting the mistakes made in season 1, but soon descends into poor writing, bad plotting and an incomprehensible mess.

I don't know where to begin. Let's start with Patrick Stewart. He is a shadow of his former Picard on every level. Annoyingly feeble. The plotline is a dog's breakfast of thoughts loosely strung together with the appearances of all the most annoying characters of the franchise. Flashbacks containing other flashbacks with dialog that makes no sense. It's like a program written, produced, and directed by people with no destination in mind or people who all are in the early stages of dementia. I've been watch ST since the beginning of the franchise and I've never seen such a mess.
Horrible, I gave up after this immigration raid. OMG..

It was a shit show almost from the start. The writers should never be black listed for the rest of their lives. Kurtzman once again drive another nail into Star Treks coffin, whose dick does he suck to keep from being fired after so many years of utter failure? Why is Stewart willing to have anything to do with this? He can't be that broke, and he has to know how much it's ruining his legacy.
Episode 6 and 7 are horrible so boring.

I don't get why a website (this one)  would go to such extremes of ambiguous redaction to try to make a turd look like fresh fruit. Sturd Trek Picard, season 2. Now he is living a robot travelling back in time to make a whole season in the street. Anyway, watch it for the comedy value of every single line of the scripts.
Unwatchable, simple like that. Do not waste your time or money on it.
Season 2 is just way too slow. It feels like they stretched 1 episode into an entire season.
Unwatchable. Trash characters thanks to awful writing, as a Star Wars fan I feel sorry for my Trekkie brothers & sisters.
I hope to see more while Sir Pat Stewart is still willing and inspired to play his legendary role and add more adventures to his stories ficitional life.

Practically unwatchable. This is the furthest thing from the Jean Luc Picard we know and Star Trek itself. It makes you wonder what the writers were thinking and if they even understand the characters they have control over.

What was the point? Why would Star Trek be set in the present? No-one has ever watched Star Trek to watch it in the present. And it's just dull. The story is so slow and boring. Some old ancestor of Picard needs to go on a mission to one of Saturn or Jupiter's moons (who cares which, right??) - and they have to make sure it happens - this is the story, yes? I just do not understand the point of this terrible, unimaginative story. I hate Q, but I kept wondering why he wasn't appearing in it more...! It's just tragic that the first season was so epic and delightful. And this one is a journey of underwhelming nothingness. I don't care if there's another season now. It's just ruined.

Poorly written. I found some of the Borg queen stuff quite good, but apart from that I was constantly laughing when I shouldn't have been, and shouting at the characters every time something stupid happens, which was a lot.
Pity really, as my hopes were up after liking the first two episodes. The following episodes went right over a cliff.
Why does every single TV show have to be about brave rebels against some sort of fascism. I feel like I could have been watching any show anywhere. What happened to star trek ? So sad
It's hard to believe season one was a 10 for me and season two is the perfect example of a rotten tomato.

It's not a complete bag of doo-doo but it really isn't very good. STP suffers from irksome, eye-rolling dialogue and erratic plot developments robbing potential viewing enjoyment and satisfaction, despite a capable cast. The plot lines are contrived in order to shoehorn current political situations in but completely lacking the intellectual depth in order to explore them. If you had never seen any Star Trek before, it is a pretty lacklustre series that simply passes time. For people who are ST fans, it may well be extra-disappointing due to how far it falls short of the potential of what it could have been and how little this show really understands, or respects, of the fundamental philosophy that created and drove the ST universe.

Uh oh, Trek has gone meta, but did they mean to? We binge watched season 1, which was a chore, and made it to episode 7 of this go-nowhere style of writing which seems to be lots of meandering random threads no one has the slightest interest in, put together by a bunch of people who apparently don't even speak the same language.  Why the heck would anyone want to watch 10 hours of what is laughingly called Star Trek that is spent in the the current day listening to whinging irritating and unrelatable child-characters in grownup bodies beating the viewer up by telling them what a bad person they are for living in 2022? WE GET THAT IN THE NEWS EVERY DAY AND WATCH THIS TO ESCAPE FROM IT!
We felt that instead of wasting a further 3 hours to get some form of payoff, it was better to spend 10 minutes here and then have nearly 3 hours of our life back. RIP the 18 hours our our life wasted (about 1-2 hours of that was horribly dated title sequences styles from Marvel and "last time" montages).
I would cut off my right arm and give it to you if I could rate this zero stars, as that's how many you'll see spending hour after hour in daytime LA dozing off.

This show is infuriating. It never fails to miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity. 
It's clear the writers know very little of the source material and characters. Much of the time they either do things entirely inconsistent with what's already been established and reinforced multiple times in OG Star Trek, or just outright make up complete nonsense plot lines which go nowhere.
Anyone who has seen the recent Matrix revolutions movie will understand exactly how outdated and peculiar this terrible sequel to TNG is, and how embarrassing it is to see Star Trek being cannibalizeed and spat back out again by people who think they know what they are doing, but in fact couldn't be doing it worse if they tried. Sometimes I am taken aback and ask myself if they are genuinely trying to trash Star Trek because they don't care and are trying to offend and make fun of the fanbase. 

It's certainly putting a slow and painful end to any hopes that CBS and Paramount had of becoming a successful streaming platform. On the contrary, these expensive yet almost universally disliked reboots of Star Trek are providing a case study on how to completely mismanage one of the most well known global television shows, taking the franchise down with it at any cost.  There should be laws against it with the SEC as shareholders best interests certainly aren't being followed. Where are the ratings? Where are the viewership numbers? Where are the paid subscription numbers?  We can go by google search interest and see that it's virtually non existent. There is nothing here other than a personal vanity project by Alex Kurtzman, destroyer of every single franchise he's given the keys to, and yet he just bounces from cancelled project to cancelled project, after CBS already fired a bunch of other show runners who display any remote interest in Star Trek and understanding of it's product and fan base. Instead it's on this quest to calve out a new fanbase at the cost of the existing one. The general interest across the board is in cancellation, not more money into more dead end badly written garbage. Star Trek was doing better when there was nothing new on air. Now people are so unhappy with what has been done that they can't bring themselves to watch what came before any more either. AKA total destruction of 60 years in just 5.

As a Star Trek fan for over 40 years I can safely say that this season (and series) reflects some of the best traits of the show.  Topical issues discussed in the context of a science fiction setting, great acting, and canonical respect for the fictional universe the show takes place in.  What I handle things differently?  Sure!  But then, I am not a TV producer and my version of any of the shows would have been terrible.  It has given me food for thought and entertainment – everything I have wanted from a Star Trek show!
love it love it love it
I wanna see star trek not what the wrighters think of our current politics.
Liked the first season. Season two is simply awful. Don't need to add anything to what's already been said. Such a waste of great characters and talented actors.

Can't say how disappointed I've been with this show (and the new Trek series in general). What happened to smart plots about using intelligence to solve problems, characters that made logical choices, dialogue that was actually rooted in what people might say? Great to see Patrick Stewart as Picard once again, but that's where it ends. Even that is a mixed bag because they've made his character a hollowed out nonsensical version of the one we knew and loved. So many plot holes, odd choices that these characters make, ridiculous dialogue, etc., etc. etc.. After the terrible "ST: Discovery", you roped me into this because Picard was in it. I'm not going to fall for the same trick again in Season 3 when you attempt to ruin the rest of the characters from "ST: The Next Generation".
More entertaining than season one, a lot of fun.

I loved season 1 of Picard, but this just isn't good. The first episode was very bad but I stuck with it and at times it was okay but everyone is so, so stupid. The whole thing's inane. I've watched 6 episodes and I just don't feel like watching the rest. I'm just going to wait until it's over and then look up a season finale recap to find out how it all turned out.

Fingers crossed season 3 is better.

As most of new series - Not Star Trek Anymore
Stop watching it after the first few episodes in season 2. For me Star Trek was always about the a possible future in which humans have become a better version of our nowadays selves. The are not full of doubt, driven by instincts and greed. They had become something more. Willing to sacrifice themselves for the greater good. Discussing moral dilemmas and sometimes walked the line. This was why I was fascinated by Star trek TNG, DSN and to some degree by Voyager.

But in Picard's season 2 it shows pretty clearly that the crew fits perfectly in the 21st century. They are not morally superior. They are not driven by ideals. I do not know what the writters goals are. Maybe they think that they make it more realistic, but by doing is turning more and more away from this ideal world that was supposed to be the future everybody was working for. 

Admittedly this future also never fully existed in the old shows, think of DSN "Homefront" and "Paradise lost", but they were fighting for their ideals willing to make sacrifices. The characters were still upstanding people. Taking responsible even if conflict occurred. This was what the Federation and Starfleet was about. 

The new characters are weak in comparison. Giving in to fear, sorrow, greed. 

Elements from too many parts of the star trek universe are used and not elaborated on. You see the Borg cube being an element in season 1, then the Queen poping up in season 2 without any major connecting story created around it all. It feels as the writers would have looked at statistics: Which are the most like enemies in Star trek and put them together like lego. When at the end of Season 1 a Star Trek armada appeared, the ships looked all the same. Even in the early 90s they managed to put together some different models, despite the fact that special effects were pretty pricy.

All this makes it basically just another poorly written and partly dystopian sci fi series, created purely for profit. Seriously, Taking a week off, I could write a better storyline.

It pains my heart, that my most loved franchise is going to be turned into a cash-cow.

I was wary when I saw season 2 was going to revolve around worn-out tropes of time travel, evil Soongs and the Borg and it still manages to disappoint me.

It seems that every main character is incapable of making a sensible decision, while the plot moves along at a glacial pace whenever the writers aren't making absolutely bizarre, incoherent decisions.

The only reason I haven't given it a zero is the cast do a decent job with bad material.

This is really bad.  Don't both watching it.  The level of wokeness is high.  The writers clearly have their own agenda, and it is not even subtle.  This creates other problems, such as lack of pacing and action, particularly two-thirds of the way through.  Avoid.  There are better shows out there.

Star Trek Picard is disappointingly lackluster, poorly plotted and poorly paced. I wanted the deliciously familiar taste of a Château La Barre but instead it tastes like bitter ashes. 

There was a time when Sir Patrick Stewart could command the screen effortlessly. In his heyday as Jean-Luc Picard, Star Trek TNG was drawing weekly audiences of over 10 million and for good reason. He was magnetic, by turns gentle and fierce, virtuous, considered and intelligent. The stories were inspired, clever and kinetic. 

ST: Picard sadly falls so far short of its legacy, despite the best efforts of a reasonable cast (struggling with awfully written dialogue) and some very talented production staff. Is it symptomatic of a series with four supervising producers, one consulting producer, five co-executive producers, and eight executive producers?

I have nothing to add to what has been said already by others. The show is simply unwatchable. And as with others, I have to ask myself how is it possible that "top reviewers" say that it is good enough to be "fresh". Really?!
Simply boring, nothing of the classic Star Trek is here.

I enjoyed season one, but season two is just terrible, very boring predictable plot. It's like watching those garbage daytime soap opera! I stopped watching after episode 4. Starting to wonder if rotten tomatoes critics got pay to write their reviews!

I am at episode 8 of season 2, and I simply cannot believe how bad this show is. What are all the professional reviewers thinking for liking this?
Well, I read what they are thinking, and it mostly boils down to being satisfied with thrills (that are really not that good or impactful). The only thing that makes this watchable for me are special effects, music, actors' performances, particularly captain Rios, Jurati, Q (still having it) and the younger Guinan.
Whoever has seen Star Trek The Next Generation (or, better yet, the best Star Trek ever - Deep Space 9) will know that Star Trek deserves better than this.
This is just a very painfull betray of Star Trek.
Picard season 2 is awesome.  I love how it is bringing many of the characters from the past in.  An excellent blast from the past!

A hot mess... Has entirely missed the point of what people love about Star Trek. Unlikeable characters behaving unbelievably to service a dull and fragmented plot. Setting season 2 on virtual present day earth seems like an obvious attempt to reduce the budget and plays like a weird procedural. Throwing in musical numbers, tacked on romantic entanglements and a kind of Borg Odd Couple diversion amongst other random things, make for a tonal mess which consistently undermines its own credibility at every turn. Quite possibly the worst Star Trek show there's ever been including the dark days of captain Scott Bakula.

A disgrace that taints Sir Patrick Stewart's role as Picard. How are these Star Trek shows getting such raving reviews from critics when the writers make such basic mistakes as "Show, not Tell", Chekov's gun, plot devices vs character development? It's high school freshman level English, people! 

The only episode that resembled Star Trek this season was episode 1. 

CBS doesn't know how to do drama or sci-fi, and CBS Trek is like the ninth failed attempt at both at the same time. It's a shame.
I am 4 episodes in and it's garbage. Story lines are infested with preachy lectures without even the sense of nuance. Lazy writing and terrible acting is how Star Trek Picard will be defined.
Now we're talking. Great story lines, can't wait for season 3.

You'll never be able to look at the character of Picard the same way again.
Dull over dramatic nonsense with a lead actor who has managed to retrospectively cancel his career by getting involved with amateurs. 
This has nothing to do with Star Trek.

Desperate and forgettable wreckage plagued by childish cliché writing more appropriate to AI generated random nonsense plots. Unbelievable that they've already funded a 3rd season. Stakeholders should be very concerned that their money has been washed down the toilet through incompetence and fraud.

Mutton dressed as lamb. A comprehensive total destruction of what should have been a golden opportunity to give back to a devoted fanbase. Instead, their intelligence has been insulted with a phony product vandalised by poor writing, poor decision making and absolute lack of cohesion or direction.

What a desperate end to a 60 year old story. Talentless, soulless and devoid of intelligence. I feel insulted to have been conned into a subscription model to watch what is laughingly called "Star Trek".  It's a desperate cash grab with no understanding of product or customer. 

The standard of writing isn't even in the same universe as the brand it's peddling.
I see that CBS's share price has tanked by over 20%. It's clearly a company on life support with a flagship brand in the gutter pretending it's death rattle is an outstanding performance.

At what point do those paid to spend time producing this property theft realise that their attempt to plagiarise and hijack the work of more talented people has failed?
Soap opera writers demonstrate more understanding and skill. Surely, they must realise it by now?

You suck at Star Trek, find another job, You're not interested in science or futurism.  You landed this job with no interest in Star Trek, and you spend days roaming about sound stages trying to convince yourselves that you're in the right place.

No one wants you here. The fans don't want you here, your target audience doesn't exist.  Take the pay cheque and walk away from the cultural vandalism that no future employer can possibly see as an asset.  

You're being paid to obliterate the very role you think will build your industry experience. Talentless hacks.

Enjoyed season 1 but season 2 is really poor. Never liked ST episodes going back in time. If I want to see the 21st century I'll look out the window. 21st century police and FBI, a renegade doctor who can help, a Q with no powers and a borg queen speaking in Agnes's head had me cringing. It had so much potential with these characters. Give me ST with space, aliens, advance weapons and tech, aliens and futuristic storylines please.

It's not just bad, it's shockingly bad.  Episodes are filled with half-baked ideas that never coalesce into anything coherent or compelling.  The attempts at social commentary are juvenile and lack any kind of thought provoking critique or nuance. 
 The whole thing feels like a vapid cash grab and an embarrassing exercise in hubris by its lead actor.  It's a mess.

Had hopes that they learned their lesson after season 1 and was looking forward to an interesting alternate universe/time travel story.  But they improbably bring back all the same uninteresting, unlikable characters from season 1 (seriously, if Picard was going to go back and time and fix the future, would he bring these pitiful jerks?  No, he'd look up his old crew who have actual work experience fixing the timeline!).  There are some nice bits of humor and I like that they revealed Seven is gay (or at least bi), but it's still written terribly, going for cheap melodrama over interesting characters and compelling sci-fi ideas and sociocultural commentary.

This is a soulless show,enfashoned with amazing special effects that unfortunately can't hide the lack of creativity in the writing room. I can literally mute the episode and find no particular changes in how I enjoy the show because 99% of the script is there to cover 50' of post production and I find it very sad. I could go on but I think I made my point

What a hot pile of garbage. Shame because I really liked the first season. I watched the first three episodes and could not stomach any more. Here's hoping that Brave New Worlds is written better than this. I honestly hope that they umm... "off" Pikard at the end of this season just so that they cannot make Season 3.  Ouch this one had such promise with the Borg storyline and it just went straight to poop. Yikes.

This is hell pure and simple. I dont care that much about the Political stuff but I do care about how well a show is written and this one is written absolutly bad. Some Plots are droped the very next Episode or Ignored Plot holes so big you can fly a Space ship throught them. This whole show is an pure Insult to all Star Trek Fans who loved the good and smart writting in TNG. This show is a good example of well story telling dosnt matter we just want to push some messages out and everybody who is in favour of this isnt in their right mind in my opinion.
R.I.P Star Trek ....
Just tried to start this series, what the hell!  This is a steaming pile of PLOP!

fighting the Borg, Q, an ambitious Soong, getting arrested by immigration and the FBI  They've taken all the great adversaries of the last 35 years and mismashed them all into a nonsensical pointless plot. Just a poor effort all round.

Star Trek as a franchise has taken me for granted for too long, my money, my attention, and now just out to straight up rinse me of a monthly subscription for this sub par drivel. 

I never thought in a million lightyears that it would get to this point that I feel insulted. Star Trek is dead to me, these horrible reboots have damaged my enjoyment of the franchise and I'm done.

Congratulations, you've achieved the impossible - you've ended the franchise and turned it's fanbase against you.
You could watch the first season. But after 8 episodes of the 2nd season I still don't see where it's going and in general the whole story doesn't make sense to me.

The storyline and cast deliver week to week. All the things we love about the franchise- storytelling, character deep-dives, fun, and danger. Lots of twists and turns. Much better than Season 1 in my opinion which I would rate a 3 1/2
Great cast and great hope but its the worst Trek I've ever seen, stopped watching now.

I was SO excited for this. But it's unbearable to watch. Season 1 was okay, not great… I hoped it would get better as the cast and writers got into things, but Season 2 is FAR worse. Boring boring boring, nonsensical plot developments, none of the wonder that makes classic Trek so great. It's just a drawn out action movie, basically, and not even a very good one. The characters we've known and loved are back in name only. And I cannot stand the constant cries of "JL" from a character who hasn't earned it as far as any onscreen characterization is concerned. Lately the show has tried to delve into Picard's background, but it's doing so in a hamhanded way, heavily dependent on fantasy elements and special effects. 

In short: this is not the Trek we love. It is a weird reboot that only passes a superficial resemblance. The heart and soul are gone. It's been a slog to get to this point. I didn't make it through episode 7 and I'm done.

Smug, arrogant, stupid, self referential  cowardice.  A pathetic tone deaf series that meanders around budget cuts and places odd references to earlier better shows. You want sci fi? This is not for you. You want to see concepts fully flushed out? This is not for you. You want intelligent dialog? This is also not for you.  You want crass, poorly layed out mishmash of half thought out ideas trying to retcon the lead actors insecurities and poor understandings of the human condition while trying to pile drive social messages with less than an inch of understanding, then this is for you.  Pure and utter garbage. Essentially MAYBE 3 hours of TV being stretched to 10. What's sad is that the 1st 2 episodes started slightly with some promise. It's unfortunate that it has nose dived into a black hole.   But then since the entire franchise is run by a group with no interest in Trek, it should not come as a surprise.

A promising concept clearly thought up by people who love Star Trek, but the execution is terrible. The storyline gets more confusing and illogical with each episode; massive plot holes; and characters are all stalled in the same spots, rather than growing or changing. You can tell production was a mess by the high volume of dialogue delivered behind people's heads or off-screen. And Patrick Stewart, sadly, seems to be losing his acting chops with age. Overall, a massive disappointment.
Just gets better and better with each episode!

Star Trek has a long legacy of social commentary tied into it's stories, however in the past, the writers did this with nuance and style.  Watching Picard it's hard to feel like any of the current writers have ever watched an episode of TOS, TNG, DS9 or Voyager.       The show in it's current state is unwatchable for most Trek fans and we're all scratching our heads wondering how they could screw this up so bad.
I stopped watching the show after four episodes... and I will not watch season 3 (even if the whole crew is there...). Bad writing. I am giving 1,5 stars out of charity.

Oof.

Words fail.

Unspeakably awful.

It's sickening to watch. Makes me feel tired and depressed. Capitalism is bad because people are poor... climate change is bad because it's burning southern California villas... ICE is bad because white people deport Hispanics... those ideas, and many more, are all shoved into these first few episodes and quickly abandoned or forgotten. The writers think they have something to say about these social Hot Topics, they don't have much more to say about them other than 'these are things that exist and are worth mentioning in our show about space'.

The cast is bad (especially Rafi), and the writing is worse. It's a show that doesn't know what it is written by people that don't know what they're doing. Lots of things happen, left incomplete, tune in next week, those things are wrapped up, next thing happens for weekend teaser. Nothing is discussed (besides long over thought out plans that immediately go wrong to eat up run time), there are no moral dilemmas or scientific intrigue, but lots of things keep happening that sometimes get resolved, and there's lots of member berries. It's a terrible low brow soap opera marketed towards unintelligent social media junkies. Really bad, and bad for you.

I so wanted this to be good, but I can't find too much to like about this aside from Rios's I only work in space line... The plot, such as it is, plods along with no advancement week in week in, credibility keeps getting stretched as more and more ridiculous concepts are raised... For me,  an El-Aurian summoning a Q like a genie...like it was some kind of budget charmed spell, was jumping the shark..no wait, El Aurians being able to endure a cold war with the Q, but getting trashed by the Borg was jumping the sha......no wait Jurati singing, was jumping ....no wait, Picard getting hit by a speeding car and suffering nothing more dangerous and a slight emotional crisis was jump....no, 7 smashing a bottle to replicate how the BQ felt, and she instantly thinks endorphines...no wait.....Jurati being able to resist assimilation, Lt Hawk wants a word...
Having all the same actors playing their great great great...no wait! Shes really Romulan no wait.... and so on, its absurd. Shockingly bad,...Please either go to an episodic intelligent 1 hour plot with an occasional 2 parter where the technobabble is at least consistant with the problem, or drop this before you destroy the legacy of ST's greatest captain.
I didn't think there could be this little attention to what star trek was. This is total garbage 🗑

Unfortunately social commentary isn't what makes a series good. The initial premise of the season was intirguing but the overall quality of the story telling has dropped off quickly. Full of predictable tropes, plot holes and conveniences.
The first season was great. The first two episodes of 2. season were more than excellent I got goosebumps while I was watching episodes but the rest is pure garbage. Such a let down.
I really really wish they wouldn't make these. I never thought I'd say that as a star trek fan. Written by children for children. It's tantamount to cultural vandalism at this stage.
Dreadful and very boring

Was hopeful for a return to the Real Star Trek episodes 1-3, but that did not happen just another pile of crap very heartbreaking for Trekkies of over 40 years to watch fully of vile characters and changed beloved characters swearing with 21st century overt Political Agenda themes, instead of hope/utopia/a better future for mankind new Trek is a preachy dystopian nightmare

I want to find reasons to like it, but I can't. It doesn't respect the legacy of Star Trek. The cameos give it some heart, but it lacks the brain or soul of Star Trek. It isn't ambitious, it's isn't confronting, it isn't smart...heck, it doesn't want you to think at all. It doesn't challenge you with views, it doesn't contemplate issues; it just force feeds you the modern trends. 

They are trends I agree with, but the beauty of Star Trek was always giving you multiple angles and understandings. This is just...every other contemporary show. Where's the intelligence? Where are the minority issues?

Season 2 started off strong and then.... well, woke Hollyweird decided to ruin it like they did Discovery. Please leave your "preaching" out of Strange New Worlds. Star Trek is supposed to be exciting and adventurous with a little humor thrown in to take you away from daily life, not be a platform for liberal indoctrination. The characters and franchise deserve better.

Wow... I had such expectations for this show. There are so many cool things they could've done. Fans of TNG would likely have enjoyed a film-style adventure ala First Contact or Insurrection, but dragged out over 10 episodes and with as many original cast members brought in as possible. There was no need to recreate the wheel--just come up with a new adventure and a reason for a bunch of old retired crewmates to get together again.

But this? This is just writers taking advantage of loyal Star Trek fans to push a completely un-Trek Scifi show--one that might very well stand on its own, but undeserving of the Trek name. As was Discovery. I guess I'll have to resign to watching old reruns.

Trying to put my objective disappointed that it isn't "Star Trek" enough aside, I still can't enjoy it. The story is boring. Too obviously political. I don't care about any of the characters. The nuances they give them in attempt to be interesting are just annoying. The only reason I continue to watch is because I'm such a big fan I want to give them each week to make me like it. I'll probably continue to do so and will continue to be disappointed.

If you want to watch "adventures in space", watch it, but be aware, this is not Star Trek.
Season 2 of Picard is more Star Trek than season 1, but the bar was very low. It saddens me to see the universe of Star Trek so simplistically reduced to social commentary without the intelligence and nuance that has been the core of all the previous Star Trek series. It looks like the writers cannot create an intelligent story where they present both sides of a story and let you make your own mind about the issues. The characters behave in a way that is not in accord with how the Starfleet are shown in the previous series, they are not professional, trained, and they behave like a regular person. This is not Star Trek. Honestly, it seems that the writers of this series have not watched or do not understand Star Trek.
This season was the worse... 90% critic rating... and then they try to hide the Audience ratings. So many things wrong, and to political to even mention in a review. Please just end it.

Remember when Star Trek's social message was cleverly woven into a compelling story? This is entirely story in service of message, and even though I agree with the message, it's just tiresome how clunky and obvious the showrunners push it. Seriously? Are there no talented writers left?

Shockingly bad. The critic reviews were all here after the first episode, so they can all be ignored as the first episode was reasonable, then it all went wrong.  Occasionally a glowing 5 star user review pops up, which can only realistically be attributed to people who work in the production. 
It's subscribers that count, and I've cancelled mine. I have no interest whatsoever in what happens as it is neither Star Trek or Picard, or indeed enjoyable. The writers are talentless hacks basking in the sunlight of a once renowned franchise as if they too have brilliance, when in fact they have the scriptwriting ability and depth of an intern.

A low iq parody of star trek worse than any fan fiction I've ever seen or read. I never thought the day would come that I lost respect for Patrick Stewart to such an extent that I couldn't bear to watch TNG anymore. I don't have the words to describe my disappointment.

No Star Trek is better than bad Star Trek.  Every Star Trek fan and CBS shareholder's worst nightmare. Shocking mismanagement in every aspect of the franchise by Kurtzman has damaged it beyond repair. Star Trek is dead. Shareholders of CBS stock should be very worried as it appears that Star Trek is has met an unceremonious end in a fleeting attempt at joining the streaming model at any cost. 

The ratings continue to plummet, the fanbase has been lost, the existing intellectual property tarnished and yet the money keeps being pumped into it from fan streaming subscribers who have now surpassed any goodwill and actively want cancellation of these reboots and removal from canon. It must be obvious to Paramount and CBS now that their days are numbered as viewers turn their backs on Star Trek and now coming after them with pitchforks.
You did this to yourselves and ignored everyone in the process. Reap what you sow.

I enjoy the teasing out of Picard's lifelong emotional isolation. Even though the story is epic in terms of a terribly changed timeline, Picard is ultimately the heart of the narrative. When you really care about even one person, it rubs off on and about the billions of others at risk. You are reminded emotionally of what's at stake. 
Also, Picard is older and he shouldn't be expected to be exactly the same as thirty years before (as some have complained). No one should. The snide review I just read that wrote him off as 'geriatric' misses the point. Then again ageism automatically precludes a balanced consideration. 
Stewart/Picard have the right to be old and have value. And they do.

It started off rather poor and descended into the worst Star Trek yet made. I can only assume that Patrick Stewart has burned through his fortune and needed the money. It wasn't the script that pulled him in. 
Avoid!

Some of the older star treks had their share of shoddy and filler episodes, but they had more than their share of incredibly deep and personal stories, which is why it reaches across several generations, globally, and remains relevant whenever watched as it often becomes a proxy for personal struggles. 


I can't find anything that resonates here. It is all so shallow with no depth, no subtext, there's no skill involved, no finesse, there's nothing gained from a rewatch.  It doesn't respect the viewer and treats it like preschool children that need to be taught a lesson in not becoming bad. 


Star Trek has always led by example in focusing on the best parts of humanity by showing just how normal it is to not be conflicted, and what we can achieve with that. The Picard episodes understand none of that. 


How alien would people from the 17th century seem to be if we met them today? Would they walk talk and act like people from 2022? Of course not.  Star Trek has always projected that peculiarity a few hundred years into the future where we are the ones who would seem peculiar with our present day values and attitudes. 
In the Star Trek future it's a strange concept to not be focusing on the greater good and progression of humanity. Everyone lives and eats for free, people only go out of their way if they have a passion for something, but if they don't then that's okay too.  

In star trek Picard it's nothing like that. Everyone is angry, conflicted, they focus on what they want and openly argue about it when there's a clash. 

It isn't star trek, and I can't pretend I support it any more. Even the pre-2009 VOD and merch, it all feels like I'm somehow giving approval to it.

Unfortunately, this series appears to have fallen into the trap of the lead actor playing himself, rather than the character of Picard.  It's not that I don't enjoy his interviews and public appearances, but it's just not what I subscribed to see, which is saddening as the name of the show is supposed to be about Picard. 

That would at least make it interesting to see how the character develops in his later years, but when it's not actually Picard we see, and the other leads are apparently written by soap opera level of writer churn, we have unfortunately crashed and burned in a typical failed reboot which pays so little attention to the source material that it isn't even in the same universe. 

I don't understand who this show is aimed at. The forced nostalgia is abrupt and fleeting, like a university student who wrote a dissertation without ever reading a single book from the campus library, but instead flicks to random pages and pulls quotes in the hope that it gives the impression of an understanding through research where no actual research has taken place. The student thinks they have pulled it off, but the examiner deducts points for trying to fool them with what is clearly disjointed waffle. 

For example, a massively jarring problem with the Kurtzman reboots is the sound design. It's clear that a library of star trek sound clips is used and mashed together for things like computer consoles and interactions. There appears to be no understanding that each series of Star Trek had unique sound designs to differentiate each other as technology gradually progressed with each 7 year series.  In these reboots that's all disregarded, and I assume that whoever is working on the sound design just has a massive folder of .wav files with a file name indicating what the sound indicates. Unfortunately there's no contextual indication of WHEN they were used.  After 7 years of Voyager and several feature films in which the "red alert" sound is replaced, now suddenly they are back 30 years in the future.  The same goes for transporter sound effects. Picard uses sound effects from TNG and the enterprise D, but ignores the 7 years of Voyager and several feature films in which newer classes of ships have very different transporter effects. This might sound like Manisha, but one wouldn't use the sound effects of a Star Wars light sabre whenever someone on the Millennium Falcon fires lasers. 

That's only compounded further by the hero ship in Picard clearly not being a federation ship, and somehow has this mishmash of sounds from random series which the Star Trek fan hears as being non-sensical gibberish.  Discovery does this too, it has TNG console sounds, voyager console sounds, and Enterprise E console sounds. 
 
The best analogy would be to turn on your windows 10 PC and hear the windows 95 start up sound. It's all so out of place and clearly shows that there isn't anyone in post production who knows what they're using from the source material.  They think they do and they don't know any different, which is the running theme in all these reboots. It's in the hands of people who are way out of their depth.  What did they expect to happen with a 50 year old franchise? 

But alas, that is just one in a cascading collapse that takes two paragraphs to describe but could be done by simply having a Star Trek fan as an advisor with the ability to make decisions.  The franchise which has clearly been put in the hands of the wrong people, but who are getting paid to do it anyway and alienating what I can only assume is this show's target audience.

I can't wait for the Kurtzman Trek to be abandoned by way of the inevitable collapse of the cash cow, not because I want something better to replace it, but because we all know in our hearts that these people are laying waste to the franchise with money from two companies who are hoping for survival in the transition to a world of on demand streaming, and they are willing to take Star Trek down with them if it doesn't work out as that's all they have to keep stockholders engaged. 

CBS and Paramount abandoned the core fanbase which made the franchise value what it was, and in attempting to tinker with the components of Star Trek to appeal to a wider and less-decerning action focused audience, they've ended up diluting the brand so irreparably. Star Trek is no longer recognised as an outstanding and lasting product, but instead is a cliché of astonishing mismanagement. 


Not even the Star Trek fanbase want to be associated with Star Trek anymore. There's a distinct and clear definition before the 2009 action reboots in which Star Trek was abandoned by those with power over those who understood it.

And please, for Christ's sake, it's not the case that every Starship captain has a personal cringe phrase for issuing an order to the helm, "punch it", "lets fly", etc.  It's simply that Picard has his "make it so", and the officers he served with adopted it too when they temporarily managed his command in his absence out of respect. It makes no sense that anyone outside of his command would know of it or use it, and Starfleet captains don't get told to make up their own version.  It was so difficult to watch what is clearly a passing glance at memes become a trope by idiot writers. 

You dont understand the source material and are embarrassing yourselves in pretending that you do. You don't, and we should be clear on that. Pretending that you do has left the franchise in a worse and less profitable state than it was in when you stumbled into it, and it's damaged your careers.

This isn't a Star Trek show in the typical sense; rather, it serves as an epilogue to the life of the titular character. While it remains within the setting of the post next-Gen era, it takes a big step away from the themes of a ship vs. the galaxy, and focuses on Star Trek's underlying concept of human thought. It's far from perfect, and not without its missteps, but the show is well worth seeing. I'd give it 3.5 stars, maybe 4, but I feel the need to try and offset the number of people that give it half a star simply because it wasn't what they were expecting under a blanket of excuses.
Lazy direction less writing padded out to fill time with fan service and go nowhere sub plots

I don't know what this conglomerate of congealed BS is but it is not Star Trek. I've no idea what the so called professional critics are smoking rating this so highly. They clearly aren't trek fans or have  any clue about it. Such a shame as this season started out half decent but every episode has gotten progressively worse.
Constant meaningless tangents. Boring AF.

Sooooo boring. Kept having the fast forward to see if anything exciting happened but alas it was in vain. The funniest thing about this show is that the critics have given it 94%! Just goes to show critics know absolutely jack about what makes an entertaining watch

What the hell is this nonsense? Picard is NOT the same person from TNG. Totally different 
character! TNG Picard is a legend. This Piccard is a bumbling fool. A space drama that spends all its time on earth, without any actual drama. The characters just slide from one self created disaster to another because they are idiots. Absolutely woeful. The writers and producers should be ashamed of themselves for churning out this crap. It's an insult to Star Trek fans and Gene Roddenberry's legacy. Shane on you!
geriatric picard in a show that doesn't have anything to do with star trek? no thank you
Wtf is this shit? they should rename it another generic series on Earth. where is the SF? the exploring, the adventure, the Outer Space, the Ships.. this is .. cheap... just cheap.

Star Trek as a franchise is dead, Jim.
Building upon the dystopian, poorly-written mess of Season 1, Stat Trek Picard continues to feel like something churned out by writers whose only familiarity with The Next Generation and subsequent feature films comes from reading Wikipedia entries. This is hollow, predictable, loud, and seriously dumbed down entertainment from a franchise that used to be insightful, moving, and exciting.
Where to start.
The characters seem to have done all of their bonding offscreen, as nothing in Season 1 warrants how any of them behave towards one another now. Actors who we've seen shine in other roles are given bland, empty dialogue that was either cobbled together from an army of chimpanzees at typewriters or slightly talented 8th graders who think their work is far better than it actually is.
It's disheartening to see drivel like this and Discovery earn high praise from critics, as real audiences will tell you this is a chore to slog through. If you truly loved TNG and the character of Picard, go no further. While Season 1 turned him into a bumbling apology monkey, routinely being barked at by what passes for strong female characters in modern Trek, Season 2 features an android walking around with Picard's memories in its head. An android body that, unlike Data's, seems to offer no added benefits. Does this Picard have an OFF switch? Do the writers even know Data had one? Probably not when you consider they think you can clone an android from a single positron. It's this level of deep stupidity that hampers the series from being anything but a nostalgic cash grab, and one that's not even been done very well.
The problems with this series are so numerous that I can't even begin to adequately address them hear, suffice it so say, anything that has lumbered forth from the cultural vandals at Bad Reboot and Alex Kurtzman is Trek in name only and should be considered a what if/alternate timeline from when Star Trek was genuinely well-written, optimistic and family-friendly.
Sheer f'ing hubris. Don't boldly go, you'll only feel dumber for the experience.

Shamefully weak season 2. Hard to know where to begin with this dumpster fire. I suppose the absolutely godawful writing is the best place to start. Each episode lurches in a new direction or, like E7 (Monsters), goes nowhere at all. It's like they're passing the pen for each episode to a new writer who didn't watch the previous episode. That would be ok if each episode was supposed to be stand alone. Then, the writing within each episode is just cringe inducing. Boring, stupid storylines abound. And then the characters. Please find a nice M class planet to leave Raffi on, the dumbest most annoying Star Trek character ever. Q and Seven are being totally wasted. Jurati is unbearable (please no more cabaret). Rios seems like a token, completely unnecessary. Guinan is just really bad (Guinan from TNG was someone you'd actually want to get a drink with, but this one is glib, snarky and generally miserable). And Picard….a bumbling, senile fool that bears no resemblance to Picard from TNG. Elnor - totally flat. Laris and the Latina doctor, both uninteresting. And Data/Soong/whoever and his robot/clone daughter Kore - the worst. Best character so far is the Borg Queen. Horrible acting (Raffi, Soong, Kore). All of this just makes me sad. Destroys memory of good Trek. This isn't even Trek. Doesn't look or feel like it. Just a lame effort to milk the franchise without doing the hard work required to tell new interesting stories that build on and are true to the foundation, and lay the groundwork to extend the franchise further.

I really want to like this show. I keep hoping it will get better. But it never does. The writing is terrible and the show ends up being boring. 

It's like the writers have never watched more than a couple episodes of any of the prior series. While modernization is usually good, these characters have a long history. Yet, they keep making decisions and acting outside of their history with no explanation. 

Part of the problem is the serial design of the show. These seasons would have been no more than a single or two part episode in old Trek. But now they stretch on and on. The writers don't seem to have the talent to add compelling character growth or thought provoking dialogue. Instead, most of these episodes are just boring side plots that seem to never advance the story. 

Some of the best TNG was where the Captain and First Officer act as lawyers to determine if the android Second Officer is a person, or when the show criticizes years of war brinkmanship by having Picard tortured and showing the problems if his supposed replacement in Jellicoe. 

Unfortunately, this new show still fails to have anywhere near that level of depth. The 2nd season started off like it could have gone somewhere interesting. But after 7 episodes, I'm still waiting for the interesting bit.

I am a Star Trek fan and I liked season one. But season two brings up legacy and family history really putting the Picards(The family) the focal point for all of humanity via another of Q's twisted tests. If it was just a random person it would be more significant. We have enough nepotism in the real world seeing it in Star Trek was a poor choice.
pretty rough watch. As subtle as a duffle bag of bricks

Nearly unwatchable. Actors seem to be mailing in their performances for those last Trek bucks. The shattered glass of the introduction precisely describes the plots, as unintelligible as they are numerous.

Although it suffers from a lack of Peyton List's presence from season one, it wasn't all too bad, not as good as the first one despite having all the ingredients for making a spectacular season.  The crew that were together at the end of season one is now fractured, it's almost like an anthology with a few previous season one characters playing different characters for season two.  At least it didn't follow Discovery where they do a lot of important things only to have it all meaningless half way through the season, thank God for them not doing that idiocy to us twice...once was enough thanks.  There was a lot more character development this time around which was nice to see, though the action definitely a lot less.  Too much Borg in this series, first season was heavy in Borg elements, this season also had Borg elements...I wonder if they will rehash the Borg in the 3rd to make it a Borg trilogy.  I must admit for people from the future where crime is almost all but eradicated, they sure get arrested a lot in the past.  Season 3 will be probably the last we see of Jean Luc Picard as he is 93 as of this review...I hope they can double down on writing talent and go out with a bang rather then a whimper.  I hope they replace this slot opening with Section 31, if they replace it with that Starfleet Academy nonsense...I will be very angry and you don't want to see me angry, but seriously they have Prodigy which is technically new cadets of Starfleet just with hands on training rather then being in classes and Lower Decks which is what happens to low ranking crew directly after the Academy so do we really need a series about students at High School, I mean Starfleet.   Why not Romulan Tal Shiar or Klingon Warrior School or anything remotely more exotic and interesting.  Hell, if they had to go with the Starfleet Academy route, then throw in a twist and make it the Mirror Universe Terran Empire Academy...that would be at least remotely interesting.  They really need to take a chance and try something new, everything Star Trek has always been in the prospective of Humans/Terrans of Star Fleet.  For a universe of aliens out there, they have yet to fully devote a series or movie with something not Star Fleet let alone an alien lead.  That Calpain was too short lived as a Captain and it was still Star Fleet so that doesn't count. The logical choice would be Section 31 but unfortunately the people in charge of the decision are Human so there goes logic out the window.

A heavy-handed, poorly edited, chaotic mess. Too many writers, too many producers, directors, etc. and obviously no clue how to tell a coherent story. Instead of a plot, an improvised sequence of absurdities. Instead of a score, layers of heavy-handed, formulaic, screeching crescendos every five minutes to inform you that something momentous has happened. By the end of ep 6, Picard is mercifully run over by a car and unconscious. The rest must pathetically soldier on, and one is practically rooting for the Borg if only to impose some kind of logic on the season. In short, it so bad you'll wish you'd been assimilated.

Picard Season 1 sent thrills down my spine. Old favorites made appearances for just the right length of time, and the season brought closure and meaning to the story of one of their most interesting characters. Season 2 unfortunately feels more like I've stepped into a Comic-Con show. Much as I have loved to see the old faces, the storyline drags in a forced narrative. Jonathan Frakes had my respect as one of the directors of the Next Gen series, but even he could not salvage the experience. 2.5 stars is representative of my conflicting emotions meeting mid-way. The sheer joy of seeing the old faces and watching yet another story involving the Borg to the disappointment of a story that just does not match the standard set by the Next Gen franchise

?
 I'm not sure what's more difficult to watch - The invasion of Ukraine or "Star Trek" Picard. The difference of course is that one doesn't pay a monthly subscription to watch Ukrainians being slaughtered.
The franchise has retroactively destroyed it's dedicated fanbase, which is quite an achievement considering it being the family jewels of CBS Paramount's only remaining hope for survival in the age of streaming content. 




It's a no from me.

I've no interest in the current care-takers of the Star Trek intellectual property rewriting All Good Things in their grotesque perverted image. It's been one insult of intelligence after another with these people, and Stewart has succeeded in making his previous character portrayal of Picard unwatchable knowing that this is how the character ultimately ends itself.

Absolute dumpster fire of a revival that couldn't have gone worse, and I'm sure all of those involved just ignore the viewer reception like Trump ignores democratically cast votes. The viewers must all be "fake news"..

The critics clearly were only given the first episode to watch before they gave their glowing reviews, as that's how we all felt after "The Star Gazer".  It seemed that the production had understood how badly received the first season was and made the appropriate changes required to keep the fanbase engaged. It all went down hill like a pyroclastic flow from episode 2 and once again embarked on destroying itself, destroying Star Trek, and obliterating what little respect remained for Stewart's legacy of the Picard character. It seems to intentionally want the viewer to forget about the hallmarks of excellence that originated the characters the source material is based on. 

Low brow cash cow Star Trek for a general audience to raise CBS's crashed stock. 
Please stop paying a subscription that they use to make this awfully badly written parody of Star Trek. I think it's made for teenagers as there's no depth to it, no cleverly written drama, just childish trauma stories dragging on and on. It's a serious chore to watch for normies, let alone Trek fans.

The writers clearly want to erase Star Trek and rewrite it for a low brow audience who are happy to lap up a soap opera with Star Trek intellectual property peppered across it. 

It's bad science fiction for a general audience, and it's an insult to the intelligence of the Star Trek audience. It's quite incredible that the writers think they have done a good job. 

The plots are nonsensical filler episodes after episode that go nowhere and somehow cost millions of shareholder dollars to produce, like bad fan fiction that's found a cache of money in a hole in the ground.

This garbage is an insult to the intelligence of both Trek fans and shareholders.

Where to begin?  Hope springs eternal for the new iterations of Trek, but over and over it's shown that the folks entrusted with the franchise have the reverse Midas touch.
