They're able to push out an okay setup episode or two (which in the case of this season fooled the critics and triggered a bunch of positive reviews to get posted), but their haphazard mystery-box style of storytelling eventually falls apart.  Actually, that's too generous.  This narrative is the plot equivalent of a black hole.  It's a void of anything remotely compelling, where any shred of hope goes to die.  Character sketches are paper thin, the tone is wildly inconsistent and jarring, things happen because the writers have a thing they want to get to, with no regard for logic...  I could go on and on.  The connective tissue between episodes is absent as well.  The weak themes suggested in the first episode (Jean-Luc never embraced love??) seem to have nothing to do with what we're seeing by episode 4-6.  We're more than halfway through the season and nobody has any idea why "Q" is on the show.  Is he having a personal crisis?  Is he trying to teach Picard a (yet another?) lesson of some kind?  Does he hate Picard and humanity or is he secretly trying to help them by creating a nightmare future for the heroes to fix?  Nobody has a clue, so the main force driving the conflict of the show is a complete vacuum of motivation.  This leaves the viewer confused and wanting for any kind of stakes to be invested in.  Bah!  This is more words of commentary than this show deserves.  Bottom line, the second season pretended to shift gears from the first, but eventually all the same problems returned in spades.

The people behind this show seem to be a lazy and obtuse group of individuals, or maybe they're too scared to voice their REAL opinions to each other in fear of being shunned or fired.

You realize that in one season, TNG had an average of 25 DIFFERENT stories. 25! Not 1. Filled with adventure and imagination, touching on the deepest and most important parts of the human condition. Now what do we have? A vapid singular story, devoid of real quality, infuriatingly stretched over 10 episodes, where it drags its feet through the mud and muck of a fleeting course of nostalgia. There is no imagination in this production team. There's no true love for what Star Trek used to be, and for what the people actually want.

Where is Captain Jean Luc Picard on the show? We have Patrick Stewart pretending to be Picard, on a show called Picard. He walks and talks like Patrick Stewart. The inflections in his speech sound like he's reading off a page, disconnected from who Picard used to be; a measured, accomplished, stern, uncompromising, commanding, and confident figure. Isn't anyone noticing this and telling Patrick to, "Please, get into character"? This "Picard" is a bumbling fool with amnesia. He's not a hero. Not the hero everyone fell in love with and looked up to. I don't care that he's 81. He's not even a shadow of Picard. Joseph Campbell is rolling in his grave next to Gene.

Who are the sidekicks but a bunch of seat-fillers? It's not their fault from what I can see. It's the writers fault. They're not given the opportunity to have us fall in love them. There's no character journey for them, where we can see them learn and grow. Oh man! I'm so crushed by this waste, and I'm angry. This team didn't seem to have learnt anything from season one. Didn't they read peoples comments and take them on board? What are they doing in their offices, besides surreptitiously pandering to the destructive force of today's twisted version of social justice politics?

The real shame of this failed endeavour, is that the people running this production have planted themselves into the controlling seats. I'm sure they'll would fight to stay on them. There's too much ego and money. Replace them. They haven't earned those seats, and they don't belong on them. It has been demonstrated on ST Picard and ST Discovery. They're not "modern" shows. They're "amateur" shows, and the future will be their judges as they disappear into oblivion.
I'll keep it short and sweet first season sucked! Second sucked as well!

The confederation? ICE? homeland security? Global Warming? Seriously? Whoever is writing this crapola has injected so much wokeness into these new Star Trek series they are really hard to watch. This is coming from a diehard life long Star Trek fan. So disappointing.
Such a let down after season 1. Meanders between tedious and silly, wasting all the potential these characters have.

They had potential to go somewhere interesting. Instead, they decided to portray ICE as Nazis. You know a show has jumped the shark when it has to resort to being super woke to get any attention. If it can't stand out on its own, it is not worth watching.  And Picard well, he is just getting old and tired.
Season 2 of Picard is basically a Star Trek's Greatest Hits tour. It's fine, but the fan service gets a bit much in places.

There are two franchises I love that have always been diverse & progressive; Star Trek & X-Men comic books. X-Men might be at the best it's ever been right now while Picard & Discovery feel like a bit of a travesty.

Star Trek used to have a sort of comfortable formula to it with types of episodes. Holodeck, character building, character bonding, world building, species lore, getting familiar with the ship itself, diplomacy, & battle. The characters were mostly chill, laid, back, & friendly. Episodes could be slice of life, horror, mystery, romance, bromance, or comedy. It had a unique architecture & it was colorful; a stark contrast from your run-of-the-mill sci-fi where everything is steel grey. Where is all of that now? Everyone is stressed out, aggressive, snarky, & unlikable. There are no friends, only acquaintances. Every episode is just more of the same thing.

Season 1 was tripe. 
I nearly didn't watch season 2 at all, but episodes 1 and 2 were actually okay (not great, not even particularly good, but at least not awful) so I tried.
Everything since has turned out to be utter rubbish. It's all just filler, with no respect for the original shows, or their fans (and no, the occasional Easter egg hidden in an ID card doesn't cut it when a team of Starfleet officers have zero regard for the temporal prime directive, and canon is trodden on so heavily). This is more discovery-esque "pew pew!" Wizards in space dross.
Akiva Goldsman said ‘It's the Star Trek world. We can make anything work.' so expect whatever they want to happen to happen, with no repercussions, no relationship to science, and no real stakes. Expect not to care. 

It's just poorly written fiction set in the future, not science fiction. Science means nothing here. Starfleet means nothing here.

The swearing is still present. Don't get me wrong, I have no problem with swearing in general, but it doesn't fit very well in the Star Trek universe. I'd accept sparing use, if it really enhanced the script, but it never does.
Cowboys and wizards in space. Sigh.

I assume most of the reviews that are not completely devastating were put prematurely, after the first episode of season 2.
The first episode was a Schroedinger's episode. In itself, it didn't offer a lot, but it did set up a lot of elements. It was for the rest of the season to make something out of it. And at that, it failed.

The story itself is weak and takes unnecessary turns and detours, just to spread the whole thing out to 10 episodes. Even then, many scenes are much longer than needed, there's a lot of repetitions and also supposedly emotional moments that are inconsistent with the characters in it.

On a different note, I very much dislike the fact that they have the same actors play completely different roles in different times. It is cheap and sometimes unnecessarily confusing. Then again, one other character is portrayed by two different actors although even that makes no sense.

The only reason that this show gets 1 star instead of a half one is the overall solid directing and decent cutting. Yes, that's what it comes to. Although even here I must say that some episodes are worse than others in that regard. 

This show should never have been made. It makes no sense from the artistic point of view.  Does it make sense from a financial point of view? I honestly don't know because there are no official numbers. I assume that the international distribution rights bring in at least some money with the Star Trek and Patrick Stewart names attached to it. Maybe the Star Trek brand gets a higher valuation if there is more content released on a regular basis. It may be a tax deduction scheme.

This show is what happens when talentless, uncreative self indulgent morons think people won't notice when they remove all that was smart, fun, thoughtful and science based in Star Trek and use brands and characters in all but name only with no understanding or frankly caring less about the original source material.

This isn't Picard other than he says the name, that's not Q other than the same actor showing up,  they are not starfleet officers as they behave like spoilt Hollywood brats with zero discipline.

Awful awful awful 

And the politics my god ?!? This show has dated badly already!! I'm not American and guess what? most of the world really couldn't give a toss about hollywoods trump, border immigration, identity and gender politics obsession. The more these muppets use established characters/brands to peddle their naval gazing nonsense the more they show how vacuous and stupid they are. 

stopped at episode 6. life is too short for this lazy unintelligent junk to pollute my mind.

As for the smug snidy borg queen, racist historically ignorant Guinan, angry lesbian raffi, angry lesbian 7of9, jabbering 5yr old neurotic scientist (2seasons still can't remember name) and bumbling slurring Picard who exactly are we supposed to be rooting for here? even Q is tired and bored of this cash grab by buffoons without an ounce of the creativity and morality that created the characters and stories they trash every further minute this junk squirms on under the now worthless name ‘star trek'

Awful. This show is not Star Trek. For the show being named after Picard, he is terribly written. Whereas in The Next Generation he was wise, admirable, and virtuous, in this show he's just a geriatric who follows the plot around. The rest of the characters don't make up for this. None of them are likeable and they're impossible to get invested in. The only one I like at times is Seven of Nine because she occasionally points out how stupid everyone else is.

In older Star Trek there was certainly social commentary, but it had something called subtlety, something the writers of this show have apparently never heard of.  Having characters go back in time for an episode or two could sometimes be fun, but basing an entire season around this premise is a horrible idea. The show feels like it's constantly punching you in the face, telling you the modern age is awful and your life sucks. This isn't fun to watch at face value. The only way to have fun is to watch it as a comedy that takes itself too seriously as a running joke.

The only thing saving it from half a star is slick camera work and the acting is decent I guess, but not that it matters since it's written so bad.

The season opens very strong, good writing and performances. Unfortunately we see divindling in the shows writing as it progresses. The show is trying hard to sell us a feeling of realism, but misses on the most obvious of things, Episodes 6 features a sudden singing performance from on of the main cast members, the scene has pitch perfect singing without a microphone and a random band that chimes in for no apparent reason. We are left with no explanations other than that the singing stunt is needed in order to move the plot along. Either the writers are lazy, only there to pick up a paycheck or just plain unintelligent. Such a high budget endeavour should be able to do much more.

Ugh. I'm only into episode 6 but have yet to like it this season. While season 1 was fairly 'fresh', this is a slug of old tropes.. 

Time travel. Q. Borg. Why do they bother.

Things done and dusted over and over again. Not new. Not exciting. Not interesting.

Update: I'm up to the penultimate episode and unfortunately it's not really improving. I blame the writers. The characters just don't make any sense. 

Examples (a few out of way too many): Elnor gets killed in a fight pretty early on. Then comes back as a seeminly invincible hologram warrior. He tells Raffi: I've missed you...? Even though his character is based on the last memory before he died, when they were still together...? Who writes this stuff? 

At least the name Elnor is pretty cool. And goes well with the Elvin ears. Deliberate? But who is he? Did I miss something from season 1...?

Soong goes from professor who tries to grow in vitro humans (or at least, that's what I get from it) to Borg-commanding-warlord overnight?

I've always hated Brent Spiner in human characters. He's so convincingly evil in every role I remember him being in that I cannot like him. Sorry. He was great as Data where his "humanity" and goodness made him likeable, but in human-form he is invariable very unlikable and I suffer from the afflication that I don't like unlikable characters...

Picard is mostly a doddering old man. Not that much fun to watch, although he has his moments. But, jeez, how many memories and flashbacks can you fit into each episode? It's not as if he's any more fun when he's a seemingly hapless child with a fake French accent.

I was never a fan of his French background. Growing up in a castle, making wine. Cliché, boring and very hard to emphathise with. So they hide the ship on his old French castle grounds, but most of the street action is in San Fransisco? I know they have teleporters and such, but it's a bit of a stretch and kinda consufing. These transporters sometimes don't work and sometimes do? Seemingly depending on what the scene requires.

To be short. Nothing makes any sense and it is not all that interesting to watch. It's also very dark. Literally. So many scenes are in the dark.

So far my favourite scene is the return of the punk kid (now man) playing his song in the bus. One of a few references to "The voyage home". I didn't know that actor was a co-producer on that movie and wrote the song himself. Well done!

And thank the lord for Jeri Ryan. She's the rock around which this series maintains a semblance of reasonableness. Every other character makes very little sense at all.

Maybe the last episode will set it all straight...?

Final update, final episode. The final half of the final episode feels much like the ending of a motion picture. I made me wish this would have been that, and not have all the extraneous middle bit. And then please leave out Dr Soong, whose whole annoying arc seems to lead to nothing but set you up for another season or another spin-off series... Featuring Wesley Crusher, no less. 

The first half of the final episode clearly shows the problem with this sort of time travel nonsense: you already know where it goes, so there's just mopping up to be done, but nothing interesting.

Still. The end of the final episode is so well done and rewarding that it almost single-handedly makes up for all the failures of this season up to that point. I wish the 90% "middle bit" could have been more interesting.
As an open minded life long Trek fan of all eras, objectively I can't help seeing this show as hot garbage.  I'm forced to concede that Alex Kurtzman Trek is just terrible story telling 😕
Love this reminds of old Trek shows!! I prefer  spacebound episodes BUT really enjoying this and the BORG QUEEN is Awesome!!

Absolutely love this show, and it gets better with each episode. Dont get the negative reviews. Every star trek show brings something different to the franchise. Patrick is fantastic as always and seeing how Picards upbringing has shaped him has been great to watch as part of the overall story. Agnes, Rios, Seven and Raffi have been brilliant, love watching these characters at work.

I couldn't be more disappointed in Picard Season 2. The plot is awful and derivative (same theme as First Contact) the writing is HORRIBLE which leaves the actors little to work with.  Let me be more emphatic..the plot and writing are worse than bad...they're L-A-Z-Y and thoughtless.  I'm a life long Trek fan since the original series and while Trek has always been thoughtful, hopeful and inspired, this Picard Season 2 is contrived, limp, silly and just plain bad.  All these 'echo' characters from the past is a ridiculously lazy way to insert familiar actors/characters without a good reason other than inserting familiar characters for the hell of it.  I'm wondering whether this serious lack of quality is because Season 3 is already filmed and in the can and the writers knew they had 'all kinds' of time to fill...don't know but THIS IS AWFUL.  Doubt whether I'll exchange any more of my precious life time on watching this awful product...these writers and producers should be ashamed of themselves.

It stinks!    I am embarrassed for Patrick Stewart.   Rafi is the worst starfleet officer in starfleet history.    I wish this show was never made.     The story telling and characters in ToS, TNG, DS9 versus this drek is night and day.

This is so badly written, I gave up watching after episode 5, and I'm a die hard long time trek fan. Star Trek was always cheerful and hopeful, but these writers and producers have such a grim and cynical world view, that they can't capture it. The characters are also so bad, they have no chemistry. The act as they are all old friends, but the writers never establish that by showing, they just tell you "we are all friends" and you're supposed to accept it. The relationship between Seven and Raffi for instance, just came off nowhere, it just popped up in the closing scene of season 1, no backstory. And the storytelling is so freaking slow, five episodes in and nothing is told. I miss Rick Berman trek.

Not sure if all the negative audience reviews are fans of JJ "destroys sci-fi canons" Abrams work or just very picky folk but I think this show ROCKS.  I have seen all Trek, TOS and TNG being favorites, and to me Kirk > Picard. But Patrick Stewart is a gift, the ensemble is clicking. Borg queen and Q - loving this show.  Wish they would have flushed out the Tyrannical earth more and I do hope Strange New Worlds gets back to single episode stories, but if a fan of TNG or Picard this show will not disappoint. .

Star Trek: Picard is really great, tying together the past, present and future is what makes this series a true and genuine work of art that speaks for all of humanity. 

I see all the authoritarian, tyranist, right fascist, false-greatness propagandists at their best(actually worst) in these reviews, trying to bring this show and what it brings to the world down -- which only makes the show that much more real -- welcome to 2024 -- and what it depicts and what it will turn into may be more real than most are aware, as is the need to bring our greatest principles and virtues from our Founders and forefathers to those who will realize their great vision today, in 2024 and in the future in perpetuity and forever for our children and their children -- Star Trek continues to offer great insight into the human condition and conveys great inspiration, foresight, innovation and creativity and even a warning of what might come to pass if we are not forever vigilant and fight for what is good and right and just. 

These issues aren't political, they are about the most human concerns that have always been and always will be -- we must face them and shows like Star Trek will continue to deliver the message of the opportunities we have before us and what we must overcome.

As a 50-year old fan, who grew up on The Next Generation, I find this show insulting to the legacy of the character of Jean-Luc Picard and to the previous acting of Patrick Stewart.

While I understand the appeal of the show to many, in my subjective opinion, this appeal is force-fed by the creators trying their hardest to resurrect likeable characters, scenes, and themes from both The Next Generation and even The Original Series. However, all this feels to me incredibly forced and does not cover the weakness and lack of originality in the plot itself, bad writing, and unfortunately quite bad acting (compared to what he acted like in the past) by the elderly Stewart...

The plot tries to merge the "modern Star Trek" sensational approach (keeping the audience on their toes instead of giving them time to think and enjoy) with classic themes by cramming every single idea from TNG into a single shaky plot. Iconic Borg, Q, Guinan, "mirror universe" feel, time travel from ST4, and even the punk from ST4, absolutely everything (and more is expected). Just glued together, not quite believable, with very little depth to it (depth was the primary quality why we all loved TNG back in the 80s).

At the same time, unfortunately, Patrick Stewart is no longer in his best condition. As much as I adore the actor, I think it's time for him to retire because his character feels week and frail, not "like a rock on the outside with a soft inside", which was what we all loved about the original TNG Picard.

All in all, just like ST Discovery, it's a failed attempt to resurrect the legacy of Star Trek with rare "shiny" moments for old fans. But yes, it is understandable that it appeals to the younger generations, which seek action. Unfortunately, the appeal is that of any other sci-fi or action show, not the type of appeal that made Star Trek the most legendary franchise ever.

For everyone shitting on this iteration of Star Trek, TNG wasn't the greatest show either if you watch them now. It was pure melodrama...in space. As was the original ST, TNG was a product of its time. The same will probably apply to this one too.

EDIT: Review Updated and lowered from 1.5 stars to 0.5 stars. The Hope I expressed for the first episodes has been entirely wiped out!

They continue to ruin Star Trek with cringe dialogues and characters we saw in Season 1 and their political activism from the real world: Star Trek always envisioned a better world but has not taken real work policies and interpreted them in the eyes of a certain political ideology just to trash or promote them. This stuff is so cringe. 

The good things *very very very little*

The Positives - SPOILER ALERT:
- They learned from their mistake of this ridiculous fleet scene from season 1. We were able to see many ships that are dear to fans such as the Akira, Excelsior or Nebula Class. Awesome. That's about it. Few seconds out of many hours. Wow.

The BAD (Spoiler Alert):

-The totalitarian xenophobic human empire that exists is not really believable. I mean it is the 24th/25th century and they are still fighting the Vulcans even though the Vulcans are pretty close to Earth relatively speaking. Shouldn't they have been eradicated or subjugated first after First Contact? I mean the Terran Empire was WAY more believable: There, the humans stole & reverse engineer Vulcan tech, then united with the common cause of the perceived alien threat and started to subjugate species after species. Many of those were integrated into the empire as citizens even (similar to how the Roman Empire handled it where it got its inspiration) but eventually softening the policies led to rebellions among the more recently conquered aliens which then sparked a domino effect and the demise of the Terran Empire. 
Here, with this bland fascist empire, there is no logic behind that totalitarian state, somehow the world ended up entirely as fascist due to a single event in 2024 for which they time to travel now to stop it. Ok, fair enough, but overly simplistic...
- They really take contested and hotly debated issues from American politics and mix them into the series... please leave your activism out of Star Trek. Focus on the plot, the narrative and the positive nature of Trek without acting like a subtle political platform that could only come from people in their Hollywood bubbles... cringe!
- The Borg Collective did suffer a major blow after the events we could see in the last episode of VOY but to make the Borg look like they are almost extinct makes no sense either from a plot perspective. Having received a serious blow for sure, but the almost demise of the Borg Empire? That is a bit too much and takes away an important antagonistic faction, probably the most fascinating enemy of the Federation.

The biggest thing after Episode 9? They turn the Borg into a faction that could potentially "do good" where Jurati (such a horrible annoying character) merges with the Borg Queen, takes the ship in order to peaceful seek out people in space that need help for a voluntary collective - "salvation instead of assimilation" they say and the Borg Queen is somehow totally fine with that COMPLETE course change of what makes the borg the borg. Not only are they ruining an important and exciting antagonistic faction, they also preach that "everyone eveil can become good with just enough understanding" Ooof, Kurtz Trek is SOOOOO bad!

"Space, the final frontier..." Who doesn't get excited to sit down to watch sci-fi set in the future and in outer space, only to have he series set on Earth in our own time?! Exciting! Cheap, dull and unimginative.
So utterly disappointed. This isn't startrek, it's a sad angry parody.

I think the writers hate everyone in the world.  I would highly suggest that no Star Trek fan watch this as you can't unsee what they are doing to TNG. 
This season becomes unwatchable about half way through episode 4 when the writers proceed to butchering yet another much-loved TNG character, this time Guinan and now also Q is a mentalist.  It's become very obvious that no one in the writer's room has the slighest understanding of the characters they are writing for. The 2nd episode opens with 7 of 9 wondering around and not realising that she didn't have any implants until she looked in the mirror. Did the writers forget that she only had one biological eye too? The doctor in Voyager made her an artificial one to go around the Borg camera in there which let 7 see in other wavelengths of light. Literally the first thing she should have noticed when she got up was that she can see normally again. NOPE!  Then there's a recast Guinan who Picard recognises but Guinan doesn't know him. At this point in the timeline nothing has changed, so Guinan should still remember Picard saving her life in the 19th's century. Guinan would be dead if she hadn't met Picard. Then there's Picard telling her to stay on Earth and not go home, knowing full well that if she doesn't go home it will damage the future as she will never become a refugee of the Borg and end up on the Enterprise D. It's just one canon issue after another and it gets absurd. I think it's being written by star wars fans who don't know much about star trek.

I really get the feeling it's more of a Patrick Stewart project because the UK voted to be independent of the EU and can't let it go.  He and/or the writers have thus far utterly obliterated the legacy of the character Picard by turning him into Patrick Stewart. I have to turn it off now and just forget I ever watched it. It was a mistake. Don't make the same mistake, you'll regret it like you regret Picard's terrible death scene before immediately stealing Data's new body and turning Picard into a robot 5 seconds later after Picard killed him for a 2nd time. 

The first episode felt like a TNG continuation that we had all been waiting for, not 100% perfect but it felt like they were rebotting the terrible first season having taken on board all of the issues pointed out by literally anyone who has ever watched Star Trek. Just don't go any further than that as that's literally all there is to it. After that it turns into an angry soap box for resentful writers and Stewart who just keep shoving their political views in every scene without being subtle in the slightest, which results in offending the viewer. Morality plays are clever, this is not. I simply can't fathom why they keep pumping money into these terrible and intellectually devoid reboots.

Terrible. Shockingly bad in fact. Lasted up until half way through episode 4, but could not stand any more. Sad as series 1 was generally quite good, but unfortunately it seems to be have been hijacked by the Star Trek Discovery team and is now both not Star Trek and not watchable.

The first season was great, but now it has in of "those" messages. The message is that ICE is evil, law enforcement is generally incompetent and heavy handed, all undocumented immigrants are victims and immigrant enforcement are xenophobic storm troopers and all this leads to alternative fascist future that Picard has to save the future from….give me a break.  This will be Picard's last season.  They took an idea that had a potential Bourne Identity feel to it and turned it an antifa "told you so" PSA.  They lost me for good.

Ah, I love how immediately upon seeing the audience reviews that all of the one star ones would be because of the social issues that the series tackles, replete with spelling errors (kind sir, "dribble" is vastly different than the word drivel). I applaud the show for tackling complex issues of our day, regardless of what the internet incel troglodytes have to say about it. That being said, I do find this new season to be vastly inferior to the past one, with it feeling much more like something out of the Marvel cinematic universe than Trek; a good example would be the stupid one-liners the characters have with intended comedic value but mostly just feel out of place. The new actor playing Guinan is far too pessimistic for the character we know and love, and the timeline continuity errors regarding her history are simply unforgiveable. Perhaps the honeymoon period of simply seeing the character of Jean Luc Picard for the first time in decades made me relatively immune to the problems of the second season, but the bad writing and convoluted plotlines of the new one really feel off.

Season 1 was interesting, but season 2 is just incurable woke. Every single possible progressive agenda is awkwardly jammed into a one hour show. Picard is more beginning to look like elder abuse than entertainment and I feel really sorry for Patrick Stewart, it is like he is filming a different show than everybody else in the cast.

After Star Trek Discovery discovered new ways to make Star Trek unwatchable, I was happy to see Picard season 2 move on from a lackluster season 1 with some cool action as a combination of Q and Borg turn Earth into a dominant fascist power...  Only to see the show get back in time and struggle to give STD a run for its money.  The show has devolved into slow trips around Los Angeles to despicably depict border officials as the purest form of evil and to whine about how so much of Los Angeles just is not woke enough.  Sad to see Guinan who was part of the racially unifying glory days of Star Trek and avoided injecting her radical leftist views into TNG replaced by someone who sounds more like Whoopi on the view.  I haven't given up on the season yet, but I'm hanging on a thread at this point.  Paramount+ continues to work at all costs to make sure no high quality Star Trek ever exists again.

So TIRED of Hollywood pushing political agendas.  I have been a Trekkie since I was 10 years old, but I am SICK of themes that suggest our society is evil.  There is a massive difference between aspiring to be something better and reveling in the condescension of your culture.  Until the current makers of Star Trek figure out Gene Rodenberry's recipe for showing us what we could aspire too, instead of trying to convince its audience that it should feel guilty about its current society or culture... I AM DONE

Paramount has learned nothing as exhibited by their never-ending deluge of propaganda. They're thinking we won't notice. Proponents of socialism, that ultra-lovable bartender/social critic, boring lesbianism, "Green" above all else, et al. The Borg isn't the threat to mankind but Marquis de ICE is? Give it a rest, Brandon. Just give us a good story and stop w/the politics already! Jeez! [Edited]

Now, comparing to the first one that was on and off all the time, this one is keeping me amused. I like how they look back on us with somewhat condescending attitude. I tried.  I really tried. Even had a bit of hope after the first couple of episodes. Third was a bit ropey.

But I've just endured episode 4. Make it stop, please, make it stop. If it's not Seven handling a stolen police car like Lewis Hamilton despite never having driven before, or the evil white men of ICE imprisoning helpless illegal immigrants.... it's Admiral Picard, sorry.... "Jay El" meeting Guinan, who has no idea who he is.  Perhaps she forgot meeting him a couple hundred years previous in the iffy two parter with Mark Twain???

She then starts bleating about how we're killing the planet, generally all to mean and, despite race not once being mentioned in their relationship in TNG, we hear a line about "people who look like you [the white man] and people who look like me"

When will Hollywood stop with this wokery.  The only overt preaching I can remember in TNG was the monologue of Tasha to Wes about the dangers of drugs - memorable because it was cringe inducing then.  If people think back, we were "killing the planet" then too.  Remember holes in the ozone layer?  CFCs... but we didn't hear anything about that from the entertainment world.

Why? Because it was the entertainment world, not the lecturing world.  I'm done.  Will pretend this shite never happened and stick to reruns of TNG, DS9, Voyager and when feeling a bit sadistic.. Enterprise.

What did Star Trek fans do to deserve this? 
Episode 1 of season 2 started with an approximation of Star Trek, but then they've again gone down this dystopia plot exactly the same as the terrible first season, jamming in all current day political issues as possible with zero allegory, and it just isn't interesting anymore. 

4 episodes and the unsubtle themes are:
Healthcare
Climate change
Race
Poverty
fascism
Totalitarianism
Intolerance
Capitalism
Homelessness
Police brutality

It's all over the place, and it feels like the writers are trying to point out that their audience are terrible people. In Star Trek the future is the utopia filled with role models working their way through difficult moral situations, but in new trek they point out the issues literally without allegory, and brand everyone who lives there (us) terrible people that Star Trek characters absolutely despise. So what is the takeaway from this supposed to be? You're terrible sinners but still have a very tiny hope that you can atone for your sins? This isn't Star Trek!

So I've jumped off at episode 4, I'm sick of recasting characters just to butcher their legacy and/or bringing in the original actors who don't play the characters anymore. It's Patrick Stewart is playing the character of Patrick Stewart and wants to show you how terrible the Brexit voters are, and how terrible people who voted for Trump are, and how terrible you all are for letting democracy happen, we're all climate change deniers and completely intolerant of everyone, and then proceed to continually bludgeon the viewer across their head with it every 90 seconds.  Trek has become a platform for these people who don't respect democracy and wouldn't know subtle allegory if it bought them a drink.

I'll read the user reviews once it's all aired and then decide if I want to waste another 6 hours of my life watching, but as it stands it just upsets me and makes me angry that my favourite franchise has been hijacked by these people, and their only response is "star trek has always been a reflection of current day politics" as if that gives them a reason to be doing it constantly, every episode, all of the time, all episodes with no room for fun, escapism, intelligent thought or morality struggles. It's a teenage melodrama filled with adult characters behaving like drunken kids trying to find a party, then getting angry when they can't find it and it's all your fault.  

It's also a poor parody of other writer's previous Star Trek works. It shows a very poor understanding of the source material and creates massive canon contradictions on a continual basis. In other words - the IP is in the hands of the wrong people who are doing irreversible damage to it.

Clearly it's not aimed at Star Trek fans, it's more like a Netflix teen drama loosely based on Star Trek as either prequels or reboots like the endless Terminator movies which keep disappointing the audience, yet they still keep pushing out terrible movies. It's Star Trek in intellectual property only, and in no reality at the required standard of writing and acting the fans have always gotten from it.  It has more in common with what I have seen from the Lower Decks cartoon.

I've also been upset to realise that no longer enjoy watching anything pre 2009 either now, the damage done is sadly irreversible like a battered spouse who can't remember the happiness before the relationship became violent and hateful, and takes no comfort trying to look at old photographs as each one reminds them of what it eventually became until they finally had the strength to walk away from the abuse. 

That's where Star Trek fans are with these reboots, so it's now for an entirely different audience who are very open about the fact that they don't like anything before 2009, which should ring alarm bells that this isn't Star Trek at all, so I guess until the subscription costs no longer meet production costs, it's just going to carry on until it completely burns out and the intellectual property is sold to someone else as CBS and Paramount as a streaming service collapses into liquidation.
Absolutely terrible. Ep 4 was barely watchable. Are the Paramount execs even watching this show?! It's like it's been written by a 9 year old. It ain't Star Trek that's for sure.

Today is a sad day today I quit Star Trek.  I loved Star Trek but it's over. So Strange New Worlds looked "promising" but can't do it, Discovery is nonsense, still I had hope. Sorry you people have destroyed Star Trek for me but you don't care, because you really couldn't care less. Because TNG was my favorite Star Trek I forced myself to give this another try despite the horrid first season. The perversion continues. It was Roddenberry's vision that made Star Trek special. I tried. I really did. Halfway through episode 3 and it's all sliding down the toilet bowl. I don't care about any of these characters. There's no believable chemistry between any of them. Even Picard and Seven are unrecognisable. The plot seems like it's written by a five year old. This doesn't feel anything like Star Trek - there's no warmth or optimism or charm. Season one was outstanding until the last two episodes. This season sadly hasn't shown any improvement from that mess. I'm sure people will love it, but I'm bored already.

I heard they had done slightly better this season, so in spite of having trauma from how much I hated the first season, I gave them the benefit of the doubt and tried to watch season two. Surprise, surprise, it is no better than the first season. It has the same tedious and unlikeable cast and Picard is still too darned old. There is no joy in watching Raffi the abrasive addict, Agnes the sociopathic fake scientist, Rios the bland, and Elnor the dark-haired Legolas who gets downgraded to a red-shirt to prove the situation is serious and motivate the characters to go on emotional rampages. Seven of Nine is there too, tromping around being emotionally unavailable and supremely unconvincing. She and Raffi have absolutely no chemistry and spend no time connecting with each other in any way so basically it is the same as last season. A few cameos by classic characters (Q and Guinan) were ok but didn't really deliver much to the story overall. Each story screeches to a halt at a cliffhanger leading the watcher to wonder- wait, was that the whole episode? Really? This show epitomizes lazy writing that feels if it creates a desperate enough situation, character development isn't necessary. I'm heartily sick of the never-ending doom and gloom forecast for the future of human kind. This isn't Star Trek. It's better understood as a sick horror fantasy of exploitative producer teams who never liked or understood Star Trek to begin with. With this repulsive cast there is no saving the show and it should be cancelled and put out of its misery. I'm just waiting for them to further desecrate the memory of Roddenberry with another jarring F-bomb.

I had such high hopes for this show. How can you go wrong with Patrick Stewart? Plenty of ways, it turns out. This is not the Picard you know from the old show. This one is feeble, full of deep thoughts and always in touch with his feelings. A LOT. God, it's talky. Just like Discovery. It never stops with the relentless soul searching and these characters just never shut up about the internal struggles they have and what it all means. Good grief, see a therapist.

Gone is the commanding presence of the thirty-five years younger Picard. I know, people age. But they've turned this once imposing character into a weak mess, always questioning and unsure of himself. Stewart really seems like he's struggling here. His acting comes off as forced and strained, like he's always on the brink of forgetting his lines or unsure why he's saying them. Every word is slow and pleading and sounds like someone's grandfather shaking your sleeve and complaining nobody's listening to him. Stewart is too old for this kind of thing now. It's painfully obvious every time he's onscreen. He should have stuck with the original no he said to this.

The rest of the cast seem to be held back by this weakened, handwringing Picard incarnation. Let's just mention now that this Trek is like all the other new Treks. It's darker, slicker and much rougher than Gene's vision was. They all look great and are technical marvels. But this is missing the heart and much of the soul of the originals. A lot of it is straight up action movie nonsense complete with the same bad writing and dumb storylines. Seven of Nine is unrecognizable here now that they've shaken most of the remaining Borg out of her. Now she's just some kind of kick-assy sarcastic gay Zena Warrior Princess. None of the other characters leave an impression on me one way or the other. Cookie cutter, all of them. This is exactly what you get when a new bunch of people imprint their own take on the Star Trek world. I wasn't a big fan of the three reboot alternate Treks either, and this and Discovery leave me cold too. Worst of all? Both series are putting me to sleep in their current seasons. The writing is just boring and unimaginative dreck. If you like your new Trek served up like Die Hard, you'll get some thrills here. If you like traditional Trek, this is best left off your list.

Can't help but thinking an hour is too short….it's so good it end too quickly. In an era of binge watching this is the only thing they should've changed. Everything else however is exactly what Trek fans want. The critics want change and want something different. But these same critics aren't Star Trek fans. The new fans have got something the old fans have been bleating on about for 50 years. The formula hasn't changed. Old favourites are back. (I'd be interested to see Q's mind and the Borg Queen's tenacity up against each other for the first time. It'd be like Superman vs Batman but without the testosterone). They've also been very clever. It's clear that going back in time has been a ratings winner in previous series and film so they've added that in. Yes it's been done before, but why change a formula that works. They're aren't trying to reinvent the wheel or provide alternatives to water, they are just adding to it. Having the Borg and Q plus bringing in Seven shows that the production team have clearly looked at the shows of the past and seen what works. They've obviously looked at the ‘top 10' of everything Star Trek and included that as the base. Then they've added some really interesting characters and probably one of the funniest characters on TV. Alison Pill is laugh out loud funny as Agnes Jurati. Yes it's simple self-deprecating humour but thankfully through all that she's extremely intelligent. There's none of that message preaching going on that mirrors todays society. It just throws in action, unbelievable scientific babble, fish out of water and a race to the seemingly impossible. They have used just enough characters for one to dwell on without having to appeal to every human denominator. 
It's a show worth spending time on. Unlike other shows in the franchise, (I won't mention the D word) this one you really don't want to end. It's not a take it or leave it kind of show. It's also of an age where patience is a virtue. We have to tune in next week for the next instalment. Can't wait!

Loving S2 so far!  The cast are acting their hearts out this time around, giving the characters much more passion, emotion in interesting interplay than they had before. Big franchises often come with a cult following who likes its direction to be driven by canon and the past and then there are those who want to seek out new avenues and get a fresh audience.  You need both for a franchise to keep chugging on for decades as Star Trek has.  Some of the recent series including Star Trek Picard's season 1 did not go down well with nostalgic fans although it was generally well received by the newcomers.  With this season of Picard, both groups can relax. From the first two episodes, it has the perfect blend of nostalgia, established and new characters, perfect acting, new stories and some familiar routes that are incorporated into a taut, what-will-happen-next, one-week-is-too-LONG kind of concoction that will unite the two arch-enemies: the die-hard fans and the newbies.  As someone who owes their life's success to Star Trek, I can vouch this will keep you glued to the TV screen and you will face withdrawals after the 58th minute. So, come together and lets enjoy this ride!

Ep 1, 3.5/5, ep 2, barely 2/5 for me. Guessing you either have or shortly will watch ep. 2; once y'all have, [spoilers] haven't we done all this before? Time travel to sometime recognizable by the audience to fix a present never meant to be (and always seems to be some totalitarian, Nazi-ish nightmare, all that black & red, and jackboots). The hell are we doing here? Also, so much telling how bad things are, not alotta showing. Some prop skulls & a flat cg sky graphic. Budget cuts much? I dunno. First episode got a positive mark from me mostly for resetting a lot of the crap from the first season. Other than that, kinda lackluster. Episode 2, though…ooof. When something starts off with a plot that has been done to death, either there's gotta be a helluva REAL twist (as opposed to something old dressed horribly in Michael Bay action), otherwise…kinda worse than not having done the show at all. Any way. That new Pike ST teaser just dropped! That looks interesting, right?
Star Trek Picard is a bit like the Holy Roman Empire, that wasnt Holy, Roman, or an Empire. Star Trek Picard isnt a Star Trek show, and there is no recognizable Picard character in it at all.

After an okay-ish start, 7 episodes in it feels like there is little accomplished. Episodes are stuffed with filler plots, incredible leaps of logic and lack of common sense. Picard is but a side character in his own show and the much advertised Q had one conversation with Picard so far. Rules are made by the show and broken in the next scene, characters make leaps of deduction to make this plot limp along. Picard doesn't feel like Picard and Seven of Nine is generic action woman and is missing all of her previously established character traits. Every episode just presents you with another small mystery which if getting revealed is underwhelming. This is neither intelligent, nor Star Trek. 
But the most damning thing the producers have done is not making me care about Jean-Luc Picard.

I have watched the season 1, it was bad. And season 2 is still bad for these reasons:
the principal characters are completely useless, the Utopia part of Star Irek has
disapeared and dialogues are incredibly long and pointless. Overall, the plot is not
too bad.
Great!!!! superb!!!!  1000% recommended

A strong start into the second season, while some may consider it repetitive they did not watch the trailer to see where this will head. This is the most magnificient Star Trek iteration of the 2020s, forget USS Therapy (a.k.a. Discovery), forget Speed-TNG (Lower Decks), this is still Star Trek as we know it: people with character making difficult choices. Hats of to Patrick Stewart, an actor like no other, who has shaped not just my world view. This is a wonderful continuation of the finest science-fiction out there. Thank you.
One thing is clear and this site proves it clearly: Our society is divided into haters and people who love things. This is essentially what this series is dealing with inside its fictional realm and outside of it. Yes, we are at a crossroads - in the series and in real life. But it takes people with imagination, distance and intellect to understand this. And this series speaks to them.
Loved the first episode.  Great to see Q and Guinan back.  Their interaction with Picard is always good.
They really killed it with this one.  Amazing.  I got to episode 4 and it was so completely ridiculous, I have just had enough.  It's no wonder their company stock is in the dirt.

Even if it didn't have the star trek name to back it up, this show would stand on its own as one of the best sci fi programs on TV. The acting, with a few small exceptions, is extremely high level, the character work is great, the plotting, the dialogue, the world building, and the production level. This show is what all modern Star Trek, and by extension all modern sci fi, should strive to be.

Spoiler alert:
It is the first episode of the season but Q?? GEEZ... as this episode was going along I was like, "please not Q. PLEASE not Q."
I never liked this character in the original series and I do not like him now. 
An evolved Borg would of been PERFECT canvas for season 2 to run on after how season 1 ended.
Sigh 😕 I will watch to see what happens.

The first episode is a massive improvement on season one. Each character seems much more likeable instantly and its nice to see more action upon a Starfleet ship.  If this is anything to go by it should be an interesting Season

The first episode of Picard season two contains more character development and better pacing than the whole of the first season. The plot genuinely intrigues. Fingers crossed that they keep it together! I'll be watching this series closely.

Season 2 is even better than season 1 and it is fulfilling; finally the Borg are……watch it and find out! Good job and worth the watch. The first episode is brilliant. Amazon has taken the Star Trek property and storyline and exceeded beyond belief. How they did this I do not know but it left me surprised, excited and in awe, I look forward to watched the rest of this season!!

This season is already much better than Season one. I saw an idiot say that there are a lot of fake reviews. Anyone who's part of the Star Trek fandom or the Star Wars fandom knows not everyone is going to have the same opinion.
Season 1 was very deep and thoughtful, and the first 2 episodes of season 2 are just a different scale and a lot more fun. Both very good in their own way.

While I'm a little tired of Picard's feelings taking center stage, it looks like the adults are in charge of this Star Trek series.

I changed my mind when they had Seven driving in LA, and even worse, they brought a Borg queen to the past.  Isn't that exactly what they were stopping in First Contact?

They should have spent more time in the dystopian future to figure this out.  Picard should have killed the Borg Queen and wrestled with his conscious.

I'm also tired of everyone's emotions being the focus when they should be focused on their actions.
Great first ep. Glad they've made some adjustments after the first season. Recommended.
Fantastic - everything I love about Trek and with high production value!! Lovely character development. Great music too! Finally Star Trek how I always wanted it to be..
Several improvements were made over the terrible first season, but this is still very bad writing.

**SPOILERS**
The Borg call for semi-retired Admiral Jean-luc Picard because they somehow know he will show up in the newly commissioned, borg tech enhanced Star Gazer, the only ship that will allow the Borg to assimilate the entire Federation fleet. Amazing coincidence. Quick! Blow up the ship, Picard! That's the end of season 2 after 1 episode. Oh, no it isn't! We're going to save it by travelling back through time! Thanks Q, we can get 19 more episodes out of this trash.

OMG, What a way to start the second season!!! It's a kick in the stomach and leaves you asking for more….First season had me on the edge of seat…That first episode left me gasping…Can't wait for the next episode!
Great but just not the same as then earlier series.
Probably one of best TV shows streaming!
The first episode of this season was everything I hoped it would be.

I was very disappointed with the first series but started watching the second season as Q was a favourite character. The first episode started well: brilliant special effects, good acting, and an exciting storyline; however, then Whoopi Goldberg showed up playing what used to be another favourite character Guinan. I swore I'd never watch anything she was in again following her comments on the Holocaust and turned the programme off. It's a shame as I think it could be a great story.
Same issues that plague current Era star trek is here front and center ; unconvincing characters and cringe inducing dialog. Without legacy characters, this would be a more blatant flop.

Star Trek's recyclings based from an early 1970s vision of the future has grown to be predictable,  tiresome, and repetitive today.  Star Trek has run out of gas.  10 minutes into S2E2 I switched out to "Raised By Wolves" and my faith in the creative ability of the human mind to write an intriguing science fiction series was restored.

Light years better than the first season so far.  Let's hope that Alex Kurtzman doesn't ruin season two like he did season one.  We can hope Paramount studios learned their lesson from the first season. 
I don't think Mike from RLM can handle another bad Star Trek tv show.

The first episode was OK, the borg rebooted, no surprise as they love rebooting. The trailer for the rest of the season on the other hand looks like a complete cop out having the story set in the almost present day as if that hasn't already been done by all star trek shows, and other sci-fi shows, probably to save set design costs and imagination, 2024 honestly so very weak. The second episode along with the first is named drop central, how many familiar names can they squeeze in despite a different future would more likely mean those characters were either never born or were doing other things with their lives. Along with Picard it's more of a museum of Trek artifacts on screen with the plot seemingly heading in a Galactica 80 direction, there is nothing original in this season, its like the trek meets force awakens, with only one season after this, give it a miss, you won't miss anything.
First episode was great! From their all we get is the wokeness. Stat trek is dead Jim!
